{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Deportivo Masatepe | image = [[File:Deportivo Masatepe.png|Logo]] | fullname = Deportivo Masatepe | nickname = ''Los Venados'' (The Deer) | founded = | ground = [[Estádio José Ernesto Sanchez]]
[[Masatepe]], [[Nicaragua]] | capacity = 2,000 | chairman = José Ernesto Sanchéz | manager = | league = | season = | position = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_bluestripes|pattern_ra1=| | leftarm1=0000ff|body1=ffffff|rightarm1=0000ff|shorts1=0000ff|socks1=0000ff| }} '''Deportivo Masatepe''' is a [[Nicaragua]]n [[association football|football]] team. ==History== Based in [[Masatepe]], they finally opened their own stadium in summer 2008 after having staged home games in the [[Estadio Olímpico de San Marcos]] and [[Estadio Cacique Diriangén]] in the seasons before.[http://impreso.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2008/07/26/deportes/81584 Carrasco a Masatepe] – El Nuevo Diario {{es|icon}} They played their last season in the [[Primera División de Nicaragua|Nicaraguan Premier Division]] in the 2008/09 season[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/nica09.html Nicaragua 2008/09] – RSSSF after winning promotion in summer 2003. ==Achievements== *'''[[Copa de Nicaragua]]: 1''' *: 2005 ==List of Managers== {{col-begin-small}} {{col-2}} * {{flagicon|HON}} Martín Mena (2004) * {{flagicon|CRC}} Glen Blanco (2005–2006) {{col-2}} * {{flagicon|HON}} Edward Urroz (2008) {{col-end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Primera División de Nicaragua}} [[Category:Football clubs in Nicaragua]] {{Nicaragua-footyclub-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Similar cases */Revising the longest run-on sentence I’ve seen on Wikipedia. Most of the information isn’t helpful here and can be found at [[Wrexham A.F.C.]] anyway
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} [[File:Leeds United AFC League Performance.svg|thumb|right|300px|Leeds United's historical League position; their fall from grace follows the [[2000–01 UEFA Champions League|2000–01 Champions League semi-final]].]] "'''Doing a Leeds'''" is an [[Football in England|English football]] phrase which has become synonymous with the potential dire consequences for domestic [[football club|clubs]] of [[financial mismanagement]], following the rapid decline in the 2000s of [[Leeds United F.C.]], a [[Premier League]] club that invested heavily to reach the semi-finals of the lucrative [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] European competition, but in the process built up large debts. The club suffered a "financial meltdown" after failing to continue to qualify for the competition, and subsequently dropped down two levels of the [[English football league system|football pyramid]], into the third tier, [[Football League One]], for the first time in their history.
Since the creation of the [[Premier League]], a total of 22 of its former clubs have been relegated to the third tier (League One), of which six fell down further into the fourth tier ([[Football League Two]]). Because they had never experienced relegation to League One or its predecessors until it actually happened in 2007, Leeds was the object of careful observation by media and derision by rival fans.
==The fall of Leeds United== {{further|Leeds United F.C.#2001–2007: Financial implosion and relegation}} As champions of the final [[Football League First Division|First Division]] season, Leeds United were one of the inaugural 22 clubs of the [[Premier League]], the breakaway top division league competition formed in 1992. Leeds had sustained success in the league in late 1990s, and ultimately reached the semi-finals of the [[2000–01 UEFA Champions League|2000–01 Champions League]]. Their level of spending to do so however had exceeded all other clubs, and the club's debt level rose annually from £9m to £21m, £39m, £82m and peaked at around £119m, much of the money having been spent on [[Transfer (association football)|transfer fees]] and players' wages. After the club failed to qualify for the [[2002–03 UEFA Champions League|2002–03 Champions League]] by only finishing fifth in the Premier League, it had to make drastic savings by selling players as it could no longer sustain the debt repayments, which relied on the ticket sales and television income from the European competition.<ref name=Herald17Feb2007/>
At the end of the [[2003–04 FA Premier League]] season, Leeds United were relegated to the [[2004–05 Football League|Football League Championship]]. The financial effects continued, and with one game to go in the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07 season]], the club voluntarily entered [[Administration (law)|administration]], incurring a 10-point league penalty, resulting in relegation to League One, the first time the club had ever been in the third tier of English football.<ref name=BBC4May2007/> Subsequent breaches of financial rules in the summer nearly resulted in the club being expelled from the Football League altogether (a fate which coincidentally had befallen the club's predecessors, [[Leeds City F.C.|Leeds City]]), but they were ultimately re-admitted with a 15-point penalty to apply to the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08 season]]. Despite further appeals, the penalty stood and ultimately cost the club promotion that season.
At the end of the [[2009–10 Leeds United F.C. season|2009–10]] season, the club was promoted back to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] after a final day victory. They have been in the Championship ever since, coming closest to earning promotion back to the Premier League in the [[2016–17 Leeds United F.C. season|2016–17]] season, where the club under the management of [[Garry Monk]] narrowly missed out on a play-off spot, finishing 7th in the league and earning their highest points total in a Championship season throughout their most recent period of tenure in the division.
==Similar cases== Leeds United's decline was not entirely without historical precedent, as [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] had suffered a similarly high-profile decline in the 1980s, finishing 6th in the old First Division and winning the [[Football League Cup]] in 1980, before eventually dropping into the old Fourth Division by 1986 on the back of three consecutive relegations. [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] had become the first league team to suffer three successive relegations when they went down to the Fourth Division in 1982, although their decline was less dramatic as that of Wolves, as they had spent just four seasons in the First Division and not been as successful or spent as much money on players.
However, the decline of Wolverhampton Wanderers was widely seen as the culmination of decades of financial mismanagement rather than an extreme amount of short-term spending as was the case with Leeds. Wolves had paid a national record fee of nearly £1.5million to sign striker [[Andy Gray (footballer, born 1955)|Andy Gray]] from [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in 1979, while spending an even greater sum of money of rebuilding one side of the ground to create a large all-seater stand at around the same time.
Contemporaneous to Leeds, [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]], who were relegated from the Championship alongside them in 2007, suffered an even more severe decline and underwent three consecutive relegations, ending up in the [[National League (English football)|Football Conference]] by 2009; they too had been hit by financial problems. Luton had been in the top tier of English Football as recently as the [[1991–92 in English football|1991-92]] season. They did not reclaim their league status for five seasons.
[[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], who climbed from the Fourth Division to the First Division between 1978 and 1981, finished sixth in the [[1981-82 in English football|1981-82 season]], having led the league several times that season. However, they were relegated a year later and went down again in 1984, suffering a third relegation in four seasons in 1986 after they had almost gone out of business.
[[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]], who matched Swansea's record of climbing three divisions in four seasons in 1986, survived in the top flight of English football for 14 years and won the [[FA Cup]] in 1988 before being relegated from the [[Premier League]] in 2000. They were relegated from Division One four years later, after which they were renamed [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] following their relocation to [[Milton Keynes]]. The renamed club suffered yet another relegation to the league's fourth tier in 2006. It would have gone down the previous year had it not been for a 10-point deduction imposed on financially troubled [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]], whose financial situation nearly saw them expelled from the Football League.
In 1998, [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City's]] relegation to Division Two made them the second former winners of a European trophy to be relegated to the third tier of their domestic league (after 1974 Cup Winners Cup winners [[1. FC Magdeburg|Magdeburg]] in 1991, though that had happened because the [[East German football league system|league system]] of the former [[East Germany]] had contributed with less clubs in proportion to the [[German football league system|unified system]] after 1990; the English system by contrast remained the same); they had been [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]] winners in 1970. City had faced constant struggles in the league since heavy spending on players in the late 1970s and early 1980s had failed to translate into silverware; they were relegated from the First Division twice during the 1980s, returning after two seasons on both occasions. Similar heavy spending on players in the early 1990s again failed to deliver silverware, and City went down from the [[FA Premier League]] at the end of its fourth season in 1996 after narrowly avoiding relegation in the previous two seasons. A second relegation took them down to Division Two in 1998, but this was followed by two consecutive promotions.
In 2005, [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] became the first former winners of the [[European Cup]] (which they had won in 1979 and 1980) to be relegated to the third tier of their domestic league. Having also won a league title and four League Cups between 1978 and 1990, they had been relegated at the end of the first Premier League season in 1993, promoted back at the first attempt, gone down again in 1997 and achieved an instant return to the Premier League in 1998, only to be relegated a year later. They have not returned to the Premier League since their 1999 relegation, although they did climb out of the third tier (League One) after three seasons.
In 2004, [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] became the first former members of the English top flight to be relegated from the [[Football League]]; their solitary season in the top flight was in the [[Football League First Division]] in the [[1974-75 in English football|1974-75 season]], and they in fact led the English league after winning their opening three games of that league campaign.
In 2006, the 1986 [[Football League Cup]] winners [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] became the first former winners of a major trophy to be relegated from the Football League. They returned to the league four years later. Other clubs who have fallen from the old First Division to the [[National League (English football)|National League]] include the aforementioned Luton Town, [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] and [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]].
In 2017 and 2018, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] were relegated twice in successive seasons (from the Premier League to the Championship and then to League One).
=="Doing a Leeds"== The term "doing a Leeds" or to "do a Leeds" has since become synonymous with financial mismanagement of a football club with potential dire consequences. It can refer specifically to any club that fails to plan adequately for the financial impact of either failure to qualify for the Champions League, or of not adequately restructuring following relegation from the [[Premier League]] to avoid a further drop, or more generally, to the rapid demise in the relative standing of any club.<ref name=Herald17Feb2007/><ref name=Times20Feb2005/><ref name=Times25March2009/><ref name=Guardian23Mar2003/><ref name=Journal24Mar2009/><ref name=Mirror28May2008/><ref name=Telegraph29Apr2004/><ref name=Times16jan2007/>
Managers and chairmen, although sometimes obliged to "chase the dream"<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/portsmouth/7879229.stm "Pompey pay for chasing the dream"], ''[[BBC Sport]]'', 11 February 2009. Retrieved 11 February 2010</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/mancity/7090829/Manchester-City-making-their-voice-heard-as-United-pushed-all-the-way-in-Carling-Cup.html "Manchester City making their voice heard as United pushed all the way in Carling Cup"]>, telegraph.co.uk, 28 January 2010. Retrieved 11 February 2010. "The cocky pretenders always seem to push it too far when they are chasing the dream, but they are not always left eating their words."</ref> (the inevitable precursor of "doing a Leeds"), are often forced to deny they are "doing a Leeds" in the wake of a large investment that some analysts predict cannot be afforded by their club and may overstretch their budget.<ref name=BirminghamMail24Nov2007/><ref name=TheSun12Jan2005/> Similarly, fans may fear their club will "do a Leeds" if its expensively acquired and maintained team is unable to qualify for the Champions League<ref name=DailyPost6Feb2003/> or is relegated from the Premier League, thereby failing to "live the dream".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/david-conn-inside-sport-blog/2010/feb/10/portsmouth-cardiff-hmrc-winding-up "Crunched creditors call time on living the dream"], guardian.co.uk. Retrieved 11 February 2010.</ref>
Conversely, the avoidance of "doing a Leeds" has been invoked by managers to justify selling their best players in order to raise funds to stave off going into administration, which might lead to a relegation-inducing penalty.<ref name=TheSun6Feb2004/> Failure to invest at the expected "normal" rate in order to maintain a particular club's league position can even be labelled as "doing a Leeds".<ref name=IrishIndependent7Dec2008/>
The phrase was notably used during the relegation of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in 2009, one of the largest clubs to be relegated from the Premier League. Having bought the club, new owner [[Mike Ashley (businessman)|Mike Ashley]] stated that his investment had in fact saved the club from "doing a Leeds".<ref name=Telegraph15Sep2008/> In spite of this Newcastle suffered relegation at the end of the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09 season]], sparking fears both before and after that the club could "do a Leeds" and drop further, into League One, without restructuring.<ref name=IrishIndependent2Aug2009/><ref name=Mail25May2009/> However, the club avoided this and bounced back the following season with automatic first place promotion.
The 2010 announcement of [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United's]] need to refinance their large debt as a bond issue following their purchase by [[Malcolm Glazer]] led to questions in the media whether even Manchester United, as the most successful Premier League-era club, could be in danger of "doing a Leeds".<ref name=Guardian12Jan2010/>
[[Shelbourne F.C.|Shelbourne]] were referred to as the "Irish version of Leeds United" after winning the [[League of Ireland Premier Division]] in 2006 but being automatically demoted into the [[League of Ireland First Division]] for financial reasons.
The term has been applied to [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], who amassed debts which eventually saw them become the first Premier League club to enter administration in February of the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10 season]], leading to relegation in the same season after the subsequent nine-point penalty. [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] were relegated to League One after the [[2011–12 in English football|2011–12 season]] of the Football League Championship, due to a 10-point deduction for entering administration; a near-identical scenario to what occurred to Leeds five years previously. They were again relegated after a 10-point deduction due to failing to pay footballing creditors, this time to League Two, in the [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13 season]].
[[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] are another team guilty of "Doing a Leeds", after enjoying a successful stint in the [[Premier League]] under [[Sam Allardyce]], which culminated in qualifying for both the [[2006–07 UEFA Cup|2006–07]] and [[2007–08 UEFA Cup]], reaching the last 16 in the latter, which included a draw and a victory against [[Atlético Madrid]], and draws against [[Bayern Munich]],and [[Sporting Lisbon]]. After Allardyce's departure, the club began a steady decline, with relegation battles being a regular feature. [[Owen Coyle]] led Bolton on a successful cup campaign of the [[2010–11 FA Cup]], reaching the semi-final stage where [[Stoke City]] despatched the Trotters 5–0. This began a rapid decline that ultimately led to relegation on the last day of the 2011–12 season. The club mounted a late charge for the playoffs in [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13 season]], falling just short after a final day 2–2 draw to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] at [[Macron Stadium|home]]. Since then, the club announced debts of £172.9m in 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32138946|title = Bolton Wanderers: Debt figure up to £172.9m after losses|website = BBC Sport|access-date = 2016-04-22}}</ref> and were relegated to League One in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35948738|title = Derby County 4-1 Bolton Wanderers - BBC Sport|website = BBC Sport|access-date = 2016-04-22}}</ref>
A similar phrase, "Doing a Bradford" was coined by former [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] player [[Simon Garner]] in 2012, a scenario that he was worried could befall his former club following their relegation from the Premier League. Garner was referring to Leeds's neighbours [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]], who were a Premier League club in 2001, but had fallen three divisions to League Two in 2007 and were not promoted back to League One until the end of the 2012–13 season; the only other former Premier League clubs to have fallen to League Two are [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] (in 2006 and then 2011, and unlike Bradford they immediately gained promotion back to League One on both occasions), [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]], Coventry City and [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18179313|title = Former Blackburn striker Simon Garner raises fresh fears|last = Johnston|first = Neil|website = BBC Sport|access-date = 2016-03-12}}</ref>
[[Ralf Rangnick|Ralf Rangrick]], sporting director of [[RB Leipzig|Red Bull Leipzig]], compared in March 2017 the mismanagement of [[TSV 1860 Munich]] to that of Leeds United, drawing direct parallels between the ownership and resulting fan dissatisfaction at both clubs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/03/13/ralf-rangnick-compares-1860-munich-troubles-to-those-at-leeds-un/|title=Ralf Rangnick compares 1860 Munich troubles to those at Leeds United|last=Nash|first=Mathew|work=Here Is The City|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}</ref> The two clubs in fact met in a Champions League fixture in 2000, before both experiencing relegation from their respective top flight leagues in the following seasons. Neither club has returned to the highest division in their country since.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/893346.stm|title=BBC SPORT {{!}} LEEDS UNITED {{!}} 1860 Munich v Leeds clockwatch|website=news.bbc.co.uk|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref>
==See also== * [[History of Leeds United F.C.]] * [[List of Leeds United F.C. seasons]] * [[Premier League–Football League gulf]]
==References==
{{Reflist|refs=
<ref name=BBC4May2007>{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/6625751.stm |title=Relegated Leeds in administration |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 May 2007 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0T4nchy?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/leeds_united/6625751.stm |archivedate=23 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Herald17Feb2007>{{Cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/road-to-ruin-1.833671 |title=Road to ruin |publisher=Newsquest |work=The Herald |date=17 February 2007 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0NhKWds?url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/road-to-ruin-1.833671 |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=The first thing which comes to mind about Leeds United today is...their freefall, the collapse into the state they are in now because of Ridsdale's ruinous decision-making. They have become the biggest victim of all the money which has washed around English football in the Premiership era. Every other board of directors in the land is frightened of "doing a Leeds". |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Guardian12Jan2010>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/poll/2010/jan/12/manchester-united |title=Are Manchester United doing a Leeds? |publisher=The Guardian |date=12 January 2010 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0NPkx6i?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/poll/2010/jan/12/manchester-united |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=Scrutiny of the Premier League champions' financial results makes for eerily familiar reading. Will the weight of their debts drag them out of the Premier League in the next five seasons? |location=London |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Guardian23Mar2003>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/mar/23/sport.comment2 |title=Catchy Toon could be a classic |publisher=The Guardian |date=23 March 2003 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0N3uXGA?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2003/mar/23/sport.comment2 |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=...'doing a Leeds' has entered the language of English football. There is now an understandable worry that any club trying to haul themselves up on the Champions League ladder will crash spectacularly to earth in a couple of seasons. |location=London |first=Paul |last=Wilson |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=TheSun6Feb2004>{{Cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article187664.ece |title=More Big Footie News |publisher=The Sun |date=6 February 2004 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0MoYOMG?url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article187664.ece |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=Chelsea saved West Ham from doing a Leeds this season according to Hammers boss Alan Pardew...Pardew says the club could have gone into administration, or worse, if Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich had not bankrolled a £12.6m raid for Cole and Johnson. |location=London |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Telegraph29Apr2004>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/comment/citydiary/2884174/City-diary.html |title=City Diary |publisher=The Telegraph |date=29 April 2004 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0MetB6F?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/comment/citydiary/2884174/City-diary.html |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=He's trying to raise £450,000 by selling a quarter of the company and as his spokesman put it: "We're doing a Leeds." What, selling all the players and going down? "No, I mean a Wimbledon." |location=London |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=TheSun12Jan2005>{{Cite news |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article211183.ece |title=Dean is no Messiah |publisher=The Sun |date=12 January 2005 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0MUFRxz?url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/article211183.ece |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=Worthington denied Norwich were mortgaging their future by signing England Under-21 star Ashton. The club plan to use part of their parachute payments if they are relegated to help fund the deal. Worthy added: “We are not doing a Leeds because the board would not put the club in that position. |location=London |first=Ben |last=Kinsella |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Times20Feb2005>{{Cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article516740.ece |title=Everton 0 Manchester 2: Irresistible United march on |publisher=The Times |date=20 February 2005 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0MNJAat?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article516740.ece |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=those erstwhile fans turning on him now should ponder the fact that his £28m transfer probably saved their club from “doing a Leeds”, as financial meltdown has come to be known |location=London |first=Joe |last=Lovejoy |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Times16jan2007>{{Cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/football_league/article1293305.ece |title=Bates still focused on grand vision |publisher=The Times |date=16 January 2007 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0MEQErH?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/football_league/article1293305.ece |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=But were Chelsea not hugely in debt and on the brink of “doing a Leeds” when Roman Abramovich made Bates an offer he could not refuse? |location=London |first=Matt |last=Dickinson |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=BirminghamMail24Nov2007>{{Cite news |url=http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/0200sport/globalsport/tm_headline=sullivan-bitter-manager-wouldn-t-have-been-good-for-birmingham-city&method=full&objectid=20156200&siteid=50002-name_page.html |title=Sullivan: Bitter manager wouldn't have been good for Birmingham City |publisher=Trinity Mirror |work=Birmingham Mail |date=24 November 2007 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |quote=As for a lack of funds, Sullivan said: "We've spent all the money we can afford as a club, without doing a Leeds United. }}</ref>
<ref name=DailyPost6Feb2003>{{Cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-97324407.html |title=Parry Vows To Keep Top Players |publisher=Trinity Mirror |work=Daily Post |date=6 February 2003 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0LpYvQV?url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-97324407.html |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=RICK PARRY has promised Liverpool will not be forced into `doing a Leeds' by selling off their best players - even if they fail to qualify for next season's Champions League. |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Mirror28May2008>{{Cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/2008/05/28/birmingham-city-in-danger-of-doing-a-leeds-115875-20432093/ |title=Birmingham City in danger of 'doing a Leeds' |publisher=Daily Mirror |date=28 May 2008 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0LK0mPY?url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/2008/05/28/birmingham-city-in-danger-of-doing-a-leeds-115875-20432093/ |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=David Gold fears relegated Birmingham could end up dropping another division to League One - like Leeds - unless the club's mutinous mood changes |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Telegraph15Sep2008>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/2958966/Marlon-King-in-court-of-Newcastles-St-James-as-Mike-Ashley-steers-clear---Football.html |title=Mike Ashley pledges to do 'what’s best for Newcastle’ |publisher=The Telegraph |date=15 September 2008 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0L7rdnJ?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/2958966/Marlon-King-in-court-of-Newcastles-St-James-as-Mike-Ashley-steers-clear---Football.html |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=Ashley insisted that he had saved Newcastle from “doing a Leeds”. “Unless I had come into the club then it might not have survived,” |location=London |first=Rob |last=Stewart |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=IrishIndependent7Dec2008>{{Cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/no-compensation-for-robbie-amid-a-rising-tally-of-missed-sitters-1566393.html |title=No compensation for Robbie amid a rising tally of missed sitters |publisher=Irish Independent |date=7 December 2008 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0Kndejd?url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/no-compensation-for-robbie-amid-a-rising-tally-of-missed-sitters-1566393.html |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=Liverpool fans may think that if they had not lost Fernando Torres for much of the season they would now be 12 points clear. This would, however, increase the possibility of them "doing a Newcastle" something that cannot be countenanced while their American owners appear intent on "doing a Leeds". |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Times25March2009>{{Cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/the_tls/article5973019.ece? |title=Damned to football |publisher=The Times |date=25 March 2009 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0Kkbsjq?url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/the_tls/article5973019.ece |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=This is the fate to which Peter Ridsdale, the chairman from 1997 until 2003, consigned the club with his profligacy and risk-taking; the phrase “doing a Leeds” is now a recognized one to describe a major club that fades away |location=London |first=Leo |last=Robson |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Mail25May2009>{{Cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1187193/What-pages-say-The-world-ponders-Alan-Shearers-future-cites-million-reasons-Newcastles-relegation.html |title=What the back pages say: The world ponders Alan Shearer's future as he cites a million reasons for Newcastle's relegation while Sbragia quits Sunderland |publisher=Daily Mail |date=25 May 2009 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0KL9pHI?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1187193/What-pages-say-The-world-ponders-Alan-Shearers-future-cites-million-reasons-Newcastles-relegation.html |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=Daily Star - Alan Shearer will tell Newcastle's money men to swing the axe and make massive changes to stop the relegated club doing a Leeds. |location=London |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=IrishIndependent2Aug2009>{{Cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/geordies-need-another-messiah-to-justify--immaculate-.htmlption-1849373.html |title=Geordies need another messiah to justify immaculate deception |publisher=Irish Independent |date=2 August 2009 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0KCIrjY?url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/geordies-need-another-messiah-to-justify--immaculate-.htmlption-1849373.html |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=People warn that Newcastle United are in danger of "doing a Leeds" but it can be argued that when it comes to hubris, Newcastle United make Leeds look as modest as Dario Gradi's Crewe Alexandra |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
<ref name=Journal24Mar2009>{{Cite news |url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/newcastle-sports/football-news/2009/03/24/north-east-s-elite-outfits-fear-a-fate-as-next-leeds-61634-23217424/ |title=North East’s elite outfits fear a fate as ‘next Leeds’ |publisher=njcMedia |work=The Journal |date=24 March 2009 |accessdate=23 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n0JneSXW?url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/newcastle-sports/football-news/2009/03/24/north-east-s-elite-outfits-fear-a-fate-as-next-leeds-61634-23217424/ |archivedate=23 January 2010 |quote=the "L" word sends them into a cold sweat. What they most fear is "doing a Leeds". Leeds United famously chased the dream and fell flat on their face, a monument to mismanagement lurking in League One as a warning |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
}}
{{Leeds United F.C.}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Doing A Leeds}} [[Category:British English idioms]] [[Category:Debt]] [[Category:Football in England]] [[Category:Leeds United F.C.]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to sport]] [[Category:2002–03 FA Premier League]] [[Category:2003–04 FA Premier League]]

revision.text:
{{For|the current stadium on the same site called Exhibition Stadium during the [[2015 Pan American Games]]|BMO Field}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox venue | image = Exhibition Stadium before the Toronto Blue Jays faced the Chicago White Sox on May 27, 1988 1.jpg | image_size = 280px | caption = Exhibition Stadium in 1988 | stadium_name = Canadian National Exhibition Stadium | nickname = ''Exhibition Stadium''
''CNE Stadium'' | location = Lake Shore Blvd. W. & Ontario Dr.
[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | coordinates = {{Coord|43|37|55|N|79|25|4|W|display=it}} | built = 1948 (grandstand)
1959 (football bleachers)
1976 (football and baseball seats) | opened = August 5, 1959 | closed = May 28, 1989 | demolished = January 31, 1999 | owner = [[Toronto|City of Toronto]] | operator = [[Toronto|City of Toronto]] | surface = Grass (1959–1971)
[[AstroTurf]] (1972–1989) | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|$]]3 million (1948 north grandstand)
[[Canadian dollar|$]]650,000 (1959 south bleachers)
[[Canadian dollar|$]]17.5 million (1976 renovations) | architect = G.W. Gouinlock (1907; previous structure)
Marani and Morris (1948)
Bill Sanford (1976) | former_names = | tenants = [[Toronto Argonauts]] ([[Canadian Football League|CFL]]) (1959–1988)
[[Toronto Blue Jays]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (1977–1989)
[[Toronto Blizzard (1971–84)|Toronto Blizzard]] ([[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]) (1979–1983) | seating_capacity = 20,679 (1948)
33,150 (1959–1974 football)
41,890 (1975 football)
54,741 (1976–1988 football)
38,522 (1977 baseball)
43,737 (1978–1989 baseball) | dimensions = '''Left Field''' – 330 ft (101 m)
'''Left-Centre''' – 375 ft (114 m)
'''Centre Field''' – 400 ft (122 m)
'''Right-Centre''' – 375 ft (114 m)
'''Right Field''' – 330 ft (101 m)
'''Backstop''' – 60 ft (18 m) }} '''Canadian National Exhibition Stadium''' (commonly known as '''Exhibition Stadium''' and '''CNE Stadium''') was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] that formerly stood on the [[Exhibition Place]] grounds, in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. Originally built for [[Canadian National Exhibition]] events, the stadium served as the home of the [[Toronto Argonauts]] of the [[Canadian Football League]], from [[1959 CFL season|1959]]–[[1988 CFL season|1988]], the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] of [[Major League Baseball]] from [[1977 Major League Baseball season|1977]]–[[1989 Major League Baseball season|1989]], and the [[Toronto Blizzard (1971–84)|Toronto Blizzard]] of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] from [[1979 North American Soccer League season|1979]]–[[1983 North American Soccer League season|1983]].{{cite news |last=Beard |first=Randy |title=Blizzard Hope Revenge Snowballs The Rowdies|date=April 25, 1979|newspaper=Evening Independent|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19790425&id=bgEMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=61gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2260,2414559&hl=en|page=1C|accessdate=July 3, 2016}}{{cite news |last=Beard |first=Randy |title=Down 3 more teams, but NASL is stronger|date=May 4, 1984|newspaper=Evening Independent|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19840504&id=FMNaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i1kDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2443,1156313&hl=en|page=6C|accessdate=July 3, 2016}} The stadium hosted the [[Grey Cup]] game 12 times over a 24-year period. In 1999, the stadium was demolished and the site was used for parking until 2006. [[BMO Field]] was built on the site in 2007 roughly where the northern end of the covered grandstand once stood. The grandstand (known as '''CNE Grandstand''') was used extensively throughout the summer months for hosting concerts.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnearchives.com/download/Grandstand%20Performers%201948-1994.htm |title=1985 CNE Grandstand Performers |publisher=Cnearchives.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-01}} ==History== ===CNE Grandstand=== Exhibition Stadium was the fourth stadium to be built on its site since 1879.{{cite news|title=The noteworthy and not-so-worthy Ex Stadium has survived fires, storms and seagulls|date=1989-05-23|first=Robert|last=Brehl|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]}} When the original grandstand was lost due to a fire in 1906, it was quickly rebuilt. A second fire destroyed the stadium in 1947, which led to the city constructing a covered north-side grandstand (known as CNE Grandstand) for {{CAD|3 million}} in 1948.{{cite news|title='To Cost Over 4 Million,' Asks Grandstand Probe|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=1948-09-21}}{{cite news|title=Fireworks Over CNE: Council Would Let Ex Boss Grandstand, Field; Fiery Aldermen Object|date=1948-11-02|newspaper=The Globe and Mail}}{{cite news|title=By Jim Coleman|last=Coleman|first=Jim|date=1948-09-29|newspaper=The Globe and Mail}}{{cite news|title=Sweet reason|first=Frank|last=Tumpane|date=1949-12-07|newspaper=The Globe and Mail}}{{cite news|title=Spring Rehabilitation: Offer to Improve CNE Sports Field For 1950 Grey Cup|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=1949-12-07}} This part of the stadium's structure stayed even as the stadium underwent various changes until its 1999 closure. Many rock concerts were also held at the stadium, both the grandstand and the whole stadium were used for popular rock acts such as [[The Who]], [[U2]], [[New Order (band)|New Order]], [[Depeche Mode]], [[Rush (band)|Rush]], [[Van Halen]], [[Kim Mitchell]], [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Bon Jovi]], and [[AC/DC]]. ===Expansion for CFL football=== [[File:Exhibition Stadium Grey Cup 1959.jpg|thumb|left|275px|Exhibition Stadium with the 1959 expansion during the [[47th Grey Cup]]]] When the [[Toronto Argonauts]] moved from [[Varsity Stadium]] for the 1959 season, a smaller {{CAD|650,000}} bleacher section was added along the south sideline.{{cite news|title=With $450,000 Stake the City couldn't lose, it was said, but it did|date=1960-08-05|last=Westall|first=Stanley|newspaper=The Globe and Mail}}{{cite news|title=CNE Stadium Muddle|date=1959-11-24|newspaper=The Globe and Mail}} In this form the stadium seated 33,150.Toronto Argonauts 1959 Fact Book, inside front cover. The inaugural game at the renovated Exhibition Stadium was an [[Chicago Cardinals–Toronto Argonauts exhibition game|exhibition interleague game between the]] hometown [[Toronto Argonauts]] of the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL) and the [[Chicago Cardinals (NFL, 1920–59)|Chicago Cardinals]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) on August 5, 1959. The game was the first time a [[National Football League in Toronto|NFL team played in Toronto]].{{cite book |last=Teitel |first=Jay |date=1983 |title=The Argo Bounce |location=Toronto, Ontario |publisher= Lester and Orpen Dennys|isbn=0-88619-033-9 |pages= 54–55}}{{cite web |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19590806&id=o9gxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kOQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=7096,863998|title=Argos Smothered By Cardinals And Lose Norm Stoneburgh|date=August 6, 1959 |agency=Canadian Press |accessdate=31 January 2014}} It was also the first [[List of National Football League games played outside the United States|NFL–CFL exhibition match]] held since the establishment of the CFL in 1958, and marked the beginning of a three-year, four game exhibition series between the leagues. When the [[58th Grey Cup]] was played at the stadium in 1970, [[Calgary Stampeders]] coach [[Jim Duncan (defensive end)|Jim Duncan]] described the condition of the natural-grass surface as "a disgrace."{{cite web|title=History - Grey Cup - 1970 |url=https://www.cfl.ca/page/his_greycup_recap1970 |work=Canadian Football League website |publisher=Canadian Football League |accessdate=23 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823210808/http://www.cfl.ca/page/his_greycup_recap1970 |archivedate=23 August 2010 |df= }} In January 1972, [[Metropolitan Toronto]] Council voted 15–9 to spend $625,000 to install [[AstroTurf|artificial turf]]. The vote passed despite five councillors changing their vote to oppose the motion, because the cost had increased from a previous estimate of $400,000.{{cite news|title=Sports to boom at CNE stadium with mod sod|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=January 26, 1972|page=14}} Two months later, contracts totaling {{CAD|475,000}} were approved to install the AstroTurf, with work to be completed by June, in time for the start of the Toronto Argonauts' 1972 season.{{cite news|title=Estimate was $625,000: CNE artificial sod to cost $475,000|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=March 29, 1972|page=45}} ===Reconfiguration for baseball=== In 1974, in a bid to acquire a [[Major League Baseball]] team, the city voted to reconfigure the stadium to make it compatible for baseball,{{cite news|title=Work could start this fall: Metro votes 23 to 6 to enlarge the CNE Stadium|date=1974-02-27|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|last=Simpson|first=Jeff}} leading to the arrival of Major League Baseball in Toronto in 1977 in the form of the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] (however, the initial plan for an MLB team called for the [[San Francisco Giants]] to move to Toronto; the proposed move fell throughhttps://www.thestar.com/sports/2008/06/28/death_of_the_giants_birth_of_the_jays.html). Originally planned to cost {{CAD|15 million}} before growing to {{CAD|17.5 million}}, the renovations, which were funded by the city and province, added seating opposite to the covered grandstand on the first base side and curving around to the third base side.{{cite news|title=Those were the days? Exhibition Stadium had it all: cold and rain and shivering fans. "Enough's enough", declared two sports nuts, vowing to build a dome|date=1989-05-23|first=Robert|last=Brehl|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]}}{{cite news|title=CNE Stadium: $17.8 million home for baseball|date=1976-06-05|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|first=Neil|last=MacCarl}}{{cite news|title=Blue Jays score in millions for Metro|date=1977-07-18|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|first=Michael|last=Best}}{{cite news|title=Forum music, CNE noise: Will they ever co-exist?|first=Bruce|last=Kirkland|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=1977-07-02}} Football capacity was increased from 33,000 to 55,000. Although the stadium was expanded to accommodate baseball, the new seats were first used for football and allowed the [[64th Grey Cup]] in November 1976 to be watched by a then-Grey Cup record crowd of 53,467. For baseball, the stadium originally seated 38,522, however by the Blue Jays' second season this increased to 43,739, although, only about 33,000 seats were usually made available (see below). Even in its new form, Exhibition Stadium was problematic for hosting both baseball and football. Blue Jays' President Paul Beeston noted Exhibition Stadium "wasn't just the worst stadium in baseball, it was the worst stadium in sports."{{cite news|last1=Macleod|first1=Robert|title=Paul Beeston heads for the bench|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-magazine/paul-beeston-heads-for-the-bench/article26425321/|accessdate=30 September 2015|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=25 September 2015}} ====Baseball problems==== [[File:Blue Jays v White Sox 1977.jpg|thumb|left|275px|A Toronto Blue Jays game during the 1977 season]] Like most multi-purpose stadiums, the lower boxes were set further back than comparable seats at baseball-only stadiums to accommodate the wider football field. Compared to U.S. stadiums, this was magnified by the fact Canadian football fields are almost 34% larger than [[American football]] fields.{{efn|group=note|Until the CFL end zones were reduced in 1986, the Canadian field was {{convert|40|yards|m|abbr=out}} longer and {{convert|35|feet|m|abbr=out}} wider.}} Many of the seats down the right-field line and in right-centre were extremely far from the infield; they actually faced each other rather than the action. Some seats were as far as {{convert|820|feet|m|abbr=out}} from home plate — the greatest such distance of any stadium ever used as a principal home field in the major leagues.{{cite book|last=Lowry|first=Phillip|title=Green Cathedrals|year=2005|publisher=Walker & Company|location=New York City|isbn=0-8027-1562-1}} These seats were rarely sold, except when necessitated by demand during the 1985 pennant race and playoffs, and again in the 1987 pennant race. As the original grandstand was used for the outfield seats, these were the cheapest seats but were the only ones which offered some protection from the elements;{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Curt|authorlink=Curt Smith (author)|title=Storied Stadiums|year=2001|publisher=Carroll & Graf|location=New York City|isbn=0-7867-1187-6}} the Blue Jays were the only MLB team using a stadium with such a configuration. ====Football problems==== Because the full length of the third-base line had to be fitted between the north stand (the original grandstand) and the new south stand, they could no longer be parallel to each other. As a compromise between placements suitable for the two stands, the football field was rotated anticlockwise away from the north stand.Illustration at: {{cite web |url=http://football.ballparks.com/CFL/Toronto/oldindex.htm |title=Exhibition Stadium |accessdate=2014-06-04}} Thus, the only seats as close to the field as before were those near the eastern end zone, and no seats had as good a view of the whole field as the centre-field seats before the conversion. Although the Argonauts recorded average attendances of above 40,000 fans per game in the first few seasons following the stadium's expansion, by the mid-1980s average attendance had fallen to less than 30,000 fans per game. ===Problems with the wind and cold=== Being situated relatively close to [[Lake Ontario]], the stadium was often quite cold at the beginning and end of the baseball season (and the end of the football season). The first Blue Jays game played there on April 7, 1977 was the only major league game ever played with the field covered entirely by snow. The Blue Jays had to borrow [[Maple Leaf Gardens]]' [[Ice resurfacer|Zamboni]] to clear off the field. Conditions at the stadium led to another odd incident that first year. On September 15, [[Baltimore Orioles]] manager [[Earl Weaver]] pulled his team off the field because he felt the bricks holding down the bullpen tarps were a hazard to his players. This garnered a win by [[forfeit (baseball)|forfeit]] for the Jays – the only time in major league baseball history since 1914 that a team deliberately forfeited a game (as opposed to having an umpire call a forfeiture).https://cooperstownersincanada.com/2013/01/23/remembering-the-game-that-earl-weaver-forfeited-at-exhibition-stadium/ An April 30, 1984 game against the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] was postponed due to {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} winds. Before the game, Rangers manager [[Doug Rader]] named [[Jim Bibby]] as his starting pitcher, stating "he's the heaviest man in the world, and thus will be unaffected by the wind." However, Bibby would never make it to the mound. Two Rangers batters complained about dirt swirling in their eyes, and Blue Jays starting pitcher [[Jim Clancy (baseball)|Jim Clancy]] was blown off balance several times. The umpires stopped the game after only six pitches. After a 30-minute delay, the game was called off.https://www.thestar.com/yourtoronto/once-upon-a-city-archives/2016/03/31/once-upon-a-city-mistake-by-the-lakes-troubled-place-in-toronto-history.html The stadium also occasionally had problems with fog, once causing a bizarre [[inside-the-park home run]] for [[Kelly Gruber]], when an otherwise routine pop up was lost by the outfielders in the thick fog.{{cite news | date=2013-06-13 |title=Tigers in a Fog as Blue Jays romp to win |newspaper=Montreal Gazette |agency=Canadian Press |access-date=2016-06-23 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3BoyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RagFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2774%2C1553161}} [[File:ArchitecturalModelOfExhibitionStadium Aug25-05.jpg|thumb|left|275px|alt=A scale model of stadium seating enclosed within a glass or plastic bubble which reflects an overhead light. There are nine columns of seats in the centre coloured red, two columns on each side of those coloured green, then one column on each side is blue, and one column on each side is grey. The seating is covered by an overhanging roof, and the structure has a concave arc shape.|Original architectural model of the fourth Exhibition Stadium's grandstand, from 1948]] ===As a popular feeding ground for seagulls=== Due to its position next to the lake, and the food disposed by baseball and football fans, the stadium was a popular feeding ground for [[seagull]]s. [[New York Yankees]] outfielder [[Dave Winfield]] was arrested on August 4, 1983 for killing a seagull with a baseball. Winfield had just finished his warm-up exercises in the 5th inning and threw a ball to the [[ball boy]], striking a seagull in the head. The seagull died, and some claimed that Winfield hit the bird on purpose, which prompted Yankees [[Baseball manager|manager]] [[Billy Martin]] to state "They wouldn't say that if they'd seen the throws he'd been making all year. It's the first time he's hit the cutoff man". The charges were later dropped. Winfield would later play for the Blue Jays, winning a [[World Series]] with the club in 1992. ===70th Grey Cup and replacement=== Exhibition Stadium's fate was sealed during the [[70th Grey Cup]] in 1982, popularly known as "the Rain Bowl" because it was played in a driving rainstorm that left most of the crowd drenched. Many of the seats were completely exposed to the elements, forcing thousands of fans to watch the game in the concession section. To make matters worse, the washrooms overflowed. In attendance that day was then-Ontario [[Premier of Ontario|Premier]] [[Bill Davis]], and the poor conditions were seen by over 7,862,000 television viewers in Canada (at the time the largest TV audience ever in Canada).[https://www.cfl.ca/index.php?module=page&id=33 Canadian Football League], Canada. The following day, at a rally at [[Toronto City Hall]], tens of thousands of people who were there to see the Toronto Argonauts began to chant, "We want a [[dome]]! We want a dome!" So too did others who began to discuss the possibility of an all-purpose, all-weather stadium.https://books.google.com/books?id=K1JsDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT785&lpg=PT785&dq=toronto+rally+1982+we+want+a+dome&source=bl&ots=cSclUIhV9G&sig=ylhm16fm0XASRkHM6HU_mX6YsCo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwig2Yi-kI3ZAhUI62MKHWMqDWAQ6AEIPjAG#v=onepage&q=toronto%20rally%201982%20we%20want%20a%20dome&f=false Seven months later, in June 1983, Premier Davis formally announced that a three-person committee would look into the feasibility of building a domed stadium at [[Exhibition Place]]. The committee consisted of [[Paul Godfrey]], [[Larry Grossman (politician)|Larry Grossman]] and former Ontario Hydro chairman Hugh Macaulay.Miller, David (October 7, 1984). Battle Is On for Right to Build Our Domed Stadium. [[Toronto Star]]. pg A1, A13. That same year, the city also studied a number of potential sites for the new domed stadium, and in April 1984, CN agreed to donate seven acres of land near the [[CN Tower]] for the stadium; groundbreaking began in October 1986, and the stadium, which would take on the name [[Rogers Centre|SkyDome]] (now Rogers Centre), opened in June 1989.https://torontoist.com/2009/06/historicist_the_road_to_skydome/ ====Life following the opening of SkyDome==== [[File:exhibition stadium.jpg|260px|thumb|The stadium exterior in 1992]] Exhibition Stadium lay mostly dormant over the decade following the opening of SkyDome, except for the occasional concert or minor sporting event. The World Wrestling Federation (now [[WWE]]), needing a new venue after a decision to discontinue events at [[Maple Leaf Gardens]] in 1995, held one [[Card (sports)|card]] at the stadium on August 24, 1996 for a crowd of 21,211. The main event was [[Shawn Michaels]] vs. [[Goldust]] in a ladder match.[http://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=33040 "WWF House Show"], Cagematch. Retrieved 8 September 2015. The stadium was demolished in 1999 and the site is now the location of [[BMO Field]] and a parking lot. A few chairs from the stadium can be found on the southeast corner just north of the bridge to [[Ontario Place]]'s main entrance. As is common with stadium demolitions, a number of the remaining seats were sold to fans and collectors. ====The "Mistake by the Lake"==== Although not widely used while the stadium was in operation (given the well known references to Cleveland's [[Cleveland Stadium|Municipal Stadium]]), the term "Mistake by the Lake" has been used more recently in reflection by Toronto media to refer to the now-demolished venue.{{cite news|last1=Woolsey|first1=Garth|title=Toronto's dome turns 20|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/baseball/2009/05/30/torontos_dome_turns_20.html|accessdate=August 5, 2009|publisher=Toronto Star|date=May 30, 2009}} ==New stadium== {{Main article|BMO Field}} On October 26, 2005, the [[Toronto|City of Toronto]] approved {{CAD|$69 million}} to build [[BMO Field]], a new 20,000 seat stadium, in almost the same spot where the old stadium once was. The governments of Canada and [[Ontario]] combined for {{CAD|35 million}}, with the city paying {{CAD|9.8 million}}, and [[Maple Leaf Sports & Entertainment]] paying the rest, including any runoff costs. Maple Leaf Sports & Entertainment got the naming rights of the new stadium, and has a [[Major League Soccer]] team in the new stadium, named [[Toronto FC]]. The stadium also held the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] along with other cities in Canada. BMO Field was initially built as a [[soccer-specific stadium]] with field dimensions that were too small to accommodate a Canadian football field and was operated as such until 2015 when MLSE owners [[Larry Tanenbaum]] and [[Bell Canada]] agreed to purchase the Toronto Argonauts. As part of the agreement, BMO Field was renovated to allow the Argonauts to move back to the site in time for the [[2016 CFL season]]. The stadium also hosted the [[104th Grey Cup]] in 2016 and [[MLS Cup]]s in 2010, 2016, and 2017, along with the outdoor [[NHL Centennial Classic]] game within a 35-day period. ==Chevrolet Beach Volleyball Centre== For the [[2015 Pan American Games]] and [[2015 Parapan American Games|Parapan American Games]], the old stadium footprint (parking lot) became the [[Chevrolet Beach Volleyball Centre]]. The temporary venue had bleachers and a playing area filled with 3,000 metric tonnes of sand.http://www.toronto2015.org/venue/beach-volleyball-centre After the Pan American Games, the venue was torn down to allow for setup of rides and restore parking spaces for the 2015 [[Canadian National Exhibition]] opening on August 21 of the same year. ==Facts and figures== *On July 18, 1958, [[Richard Petty]] made the first of 1,184 starts in [[NASCAR]] Grand National (now the [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series|Monster Energy series]]) competition in a race at the grandstand, entitled the [[1958 Jim Mideon 500]]. *The stadium was featured on a Season 4 ''[[Route 66 (TV series)|Route 66]]'' episode titled "A Long Way from St. Louie" which first aired on December 6, 1963. While on a [[helicopter]] tour over downtown Toronto, Tod Stiles and Linc Case ([[Martin Milner]] and [[Glenn Corbett]], respectively) spot a quintet of girl musicians (two were played by [[Lynda Day George|Lynda Day]] and [[Jessica Walter]]), who were stranded in the city, sleeping on the benches in the covered north grandstand. *1967 saw the [[Canadian Armed Forces Tattoo 1967]] perform 8 shows at the stadium to standing ovations every night. So popular with crowds at the stadium of 30,000 most nights, the 89-year-old never on Sunday taboo had to be waived to permit the Tattoo to put on a Sunday September 3 performance to accommodate the extraordinary demand for tickets. John Holden, a CNE official stated, "It was breathtaking. You just can’t compare it with the like of anything that has come before it." CNE General Manager Bert Powell stated, "We’ve never had anything like it — fabulous and fantastic. My phone is never quiet. I’m even getting professional critics and entertainers begging for tickets, and that's the ultimate tribute." *[[Soccer Bowl '81]] was played at Exhibition Stadium. *In 1982, the [[70th Grey Cup]] game held at the stadium had the largest number of television viewers in Canadian history, with 7,862,000. The record has since been broken. *[[The Jacksons]] performed three concerts at the stadium on October 5, 6 and 7, 1984 during their [[Victory Tour (The Jacksons tour)|Victory Tour]] in front of 165,000 in attendance. *In 1985, the first [[1985 American League Championship Series#Game 7|Game 7]] in the history of the [[American League Championship Series|ALCS]] was played at the stadium. The Blue Jays lost to the [[Kansas City Royals]], 6–2.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} *In August 1986, the stadium played host to the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]]'s "Big Event" card in front of over 70,000 fans. The main event was then-[[WWE World Heavyweight Championship|World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Hulk Hogan]] against [[Paul Orndorff]]. This event did not air on pay-per-view. {{citation needed|date=June 2015}} * [[Van Halen]] August 18, 1986 capacity concert sellout the first new tour with [[Sammy Hagar]] as lead singer * [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] sold out the stadium on September 22, 1986 at 8:00 P.M. to a sold-out crowd of 61,000 people as a part of their North American leg of [[The Invisible Touch Tour]]. * [[U2]] played the stadium on the [[Joshua Tree Tour]] on October 3, 1987, and on the [[Zoo_TV_Tour|ZooTV Tour]] on September 5 and 6, 1992. *[[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] brought her [[Who's That Girl World Tour]] to the stadium on July 4, 1987 before a sold out crowd of 50,013 people. *[[Pink Floyd]] performed there three concerts on September 21, 22 and 23, 1987 and next year on May 13, 1988 as part of their [[A Momentary Lapse of Reason Tour]]. They returned to the stadium for three nights on July 5, 6 and 7, 1994 as part of their [[The Division Bell Tour]]. *[[Guns N' Roses]] played the stadium on back-to-back nights, June 7 and 8, 1991, as part of their [[Use Your Illusion Tour]]. *[[Guns N' Roses]] returned to the stadium in just over a year, on September 13, 1992, this time on a double bill with [[Metallica]], performing as part of their joint [[Guns N' Roses/Metallica Stadium Tour]], with [[Faith No More]] as the opening act. *[[Paul McCartney]] brought his [[The New World Tour|New World Tour]] to the stadium on June 6, 1993. It would be his last show in Canada until April 2002. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |+ [[Grey Cup]]s at Exhibition Stadium ! scope=col | Game ! scope=col | {{Infobox volleyball club |clubname = Amigos - Van Pelt Sint Antonius Zoersel |short name = |nickname = |image = [[File:Amigos-VP-Logo-Verdana-300.png|180x180px]] |fullname = |founded = |dissolved = |ground = Amigos - Van Pelt Arena
[[Sint-Antonius, Zoersel|Sint-Antonius]]
[[Belgium]] |capacity = |chairman = {{flagicon|Belgium}} Claude Holvoet |manager = |captain = |league Woman = [[Liga A Dames]] ''(women)''
[League Man = EuroMillions Volley League ''(men)'' |season = |position = |pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= |pattern_ra1= |leftarm1=03015e |body1=03015e |rightarm1=03015e |shorts1=05039b |pattern_la2= |pattern_b2= |pattern_ra2= |leftarm2=fcff56 |body2=fcff56 |rightarm2=fcff56 |shorts2=05039b |website = http://www.amigos.be }} '''Amigos - Van Pelt Sint Antonius Zoersel''' is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[volleyball]] club based in [[Zoersel]]. The team was founded in 1997, as a result of a merger between VOC Halle (founded 1974) and VC Amigos (founded 1972). Zoersel's women's A squad won promotion to the [[Ere Divisie Dames|highest level]] of Belgian volleyball for the first time in 2006. The men's A squad currently participates in the EuroMillions Volley League since the season 2015-2016. Amigos Zoersel is the club with most members in Belgium. It counts 8 women's and 9 men's senior teams, and many youth teams. ==Former squad (2017-2018)== ===Women's A squad=== :[[Coach (sport)|Coach Trainer]]: {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Jeroen Rymen]] :[[Coach (sport)|Assistant Trainer]]: {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Marlies De Smet]] :[[Coach (sport)|Assistant Scouting]]: {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Maarten Adriaensen]] {| class="wikitable" ! # ! {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} '''Hawkins''' (dates unknown) was an English amateur [[cricket]]er who made 4 known appearances in [[first-class cricket]] matches from 1786 to 1787.
==Career== He was mainly associated with [[Hampshire county cricket teams|Hampshire]] but also represented the [[White Conduit Club]].<ref name=S&B>[[Arthur Haygarth]], ''Scores & Biographies'', Volume 1 (1744-1826), Lillywhite, 1862</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External sources== * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/80/80104/80104.html CricketArchive record]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hawkins}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:Hampshire cricketers]] [[Category:Hambledon cricketers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:White Conduit Club cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1787 to 1825]]
{{England-cricket-bio-stub}}
