revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum |name = Oregon Sports Hall of Fame |image = Oregon Sports HOF.jpg |imagesize = 150 |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 1980 |dissolved = |location = |type = [[Hall of Fame]] |visitors = |director = Mike Rose |curator = |publictransit = |website = [http://www.oregonsportshall.org/ www.oregonsportshall.org] }}The '''Oregon Sports Hall of Fame''' honors [[Oregon]] athletes, teams, coaches, and others who have made a significant contribution to sports in Oregon. The first class was inducted in 1980, with new inductees added in the fall. Operated by the Oregon Sports Trust, the museum is currently closed in preparation for moving to another facility.
==History and organization== The Oregon Sports [[Hall of Fame]] inducted its first class of 54 members in 1980, a diverse group that included Olympians [[Mack Robinson (athlete)|Mack Robinson]], [[Don Schollander]] and [[Frank Troeh]], Boston Red Sox legend [[Johnny Pesky]], [[NFL]] hero [[Norm van Brocklin]], [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Terry Baker]], high jump innovator [[Dick Fosbury]], and basketball coaching legend [[Slats Gill]].
New members are inducted each fall, in a ceremony held in recent years at the [[Multnomah Athletic Club]] in [[Portland, Oregon]].
==Scholarships== As part of its educational mission to promote the values and rewards of participation in sports, the Oregon Sports Hall of Fame grants as many as nine $2,000 scholarships given to outstanding Oregon student athletes who will be attending Oregon colleges. Scholarship winners are honored during the Hall of Fame induction ceremony.
==Facility== From 1986 to 1997, the museum was located in a {{convert|3000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} basement under the [[Standard Insurance Center]] in downtown [[Portland, Oregon]].<ref name=pbj>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/1997/05/19/daily11.html|title=Sports Hall of Fame finds a new home|date=1997-05-22|accessdate=2008-05-27|work=[[Portland Business Journal]]}}</ref> In 1997, the museum moved to a nearby facility featuring {{convert|7000|sqft|m2|-2}} of space with hands-on exhibits, videos, and memorabilia, such as [[Terry Baker]]'s [[Heisman trophy]] (the first Heisman given to a West Coast athlete), [[Mack Robinson (athlete)|Mack Robinson]]'s Olympic jersey, one of [[Dale Murphy]]'s [[Golden Gloves]], and [[Bill Walton]]'s jersey from the 1977 [[Portland Trail Blazers]] [[NBA]] championship game.
In mid-2008, StanCorp evicted the museum in order to expand their own office space. The museum is closed in preparation for moving to an as-yet determined location.<ref name=oshofrelo>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonsportshall.com/index.htm |title=Museum closes temporarily |publisher=Oregon Sports Hall of Fame |accessdate=2008-05-27 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926233740/http://www.oregonsportshall.com/index.htm |archivedate=September 26, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=brandon>{{cite news|last=Brandon|first=Steve|accessdate=2008-05-27|work=[[Portland Tribune]]|date=2008-04-22|url=http://www.portlandtribune.com/sports/story.php?story_id=120881302336971000|title=Museum hunts for new home}}</ref>
==Inductees== The current members of the Oregon Sports Hall of Fame are listed below.

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Arena in Lincoln, Nebraska USA" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Arena in Lincoln, Nebraska USA}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Pershing Center | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = File:Pershing Center, Lincoln, Nebraska, USA.jpg | caption = | fullname = | former_names = Pershing Auditorium | location = 226 Centennial Mall South
[[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|48|42|N|96|41|55|W|display=inline,title|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = 1955 | built = | opened = March 10, 1957 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = August 7, 2014 | demolished = | owner = [[Lincoln, Nebraska|City of Lincoln]] | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = $1.5 million | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,526 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[No Coast Derby Girls]] ([[Women's Flat Track Derby Association|WFTDA]]) (1995–2014)
[[Lincoln Capitals]] ([[National Indoor Football League|NIFL]]) (1999–2006)
[[Lincoln Haymakers]] ([[Champions Professional Indoor Football League|CPIFL]]) (2013–2014) | embedded = | website = {{URL|http://www.pershingcenter.com}} (offline) | publictransit = [[StarTran]] }} The '''Pershing Center''' (originally known as '''Pershing Auditorium''') is a 4,526-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]. Although still physically in place, it is no longer in use. ==History== In February 12, 1900, Lincoln's first municipal auditorium, though owned by [[Lancaster County, Nebraska|Lancaster County]] and operated by the local chapter of the [[American Legion]], opened. The building was burnt to the ground in an accident on April 15, 1928.http://journalstar.com/entertainment/misc/jim-mckee-what-will-become-of-pershing---/article_0b137316-de34-11df-8d2f-001cc4c002e0.html By 1931, the city of Lincoln was planning to build a new auditorium and name it after General [[John J. Pershing]], based on votes from students that would ultimately form and attend [[Lincoln Northeast High School]]. In 1939, city of Lincoln voters approved a $750,000 bond to build a new auditorium. A second bond in 1950, at cost of $1.5 million, was approved, but an additional $75,000 bond was rejected in 1952. Plans for Pershing were approved in 1955 and the building opened two years later.http://journalstar.com/entertainment/misc/jim-mckee-what-will-become-of-pershing---/article_0b137316-de34-11df-8d2f-001cc4c002e0.html ===Mural=== Pershing's exterior is highlighted by a large [[ceramic tile]] [[mural]], designed by artists [[Leonard Thiessen]] and [[Bill J. Hammon]]. Measuring 38-by-140 foot (5320 sq. ft.; 494.2 m2) and consisting of 763,000 1-sq.-inch pieces, it was the largest ceramic tile mural in the United States at the time of its construction.http://journalstar.com/news/local/what-is-saving-the-pershing-center-mural-worth-to-you/article_0d0af8b6-e5ad-5b02-9b94-02e84d7cceed.html ==Sports== The arena was home to the [[Lincoln Capitols]] [[National Indoor Football League|NIFL]] [[indoor American football|indoor football]] team [[Lincoln Thunder]] [[American Basketball Association (2000-)|ABA]] [[basketball]] team and the [[No Coast Derby Girls]] [[Women's Flat Track Derby Association]] league.Josh Swartzlander, "[http://journalstar.com/news/local/article_e13b897d-072c-50de-a67d-6229d00bfb64.html Roller Derby expo packs Pershing Center]", ''[[Lincoln Journal Star]]'', 25 March 2006 In 2013, it was home to the [[Lincoln Haymakers]] of the [[Champions Professional Indoor Football League]]. Pershing was also a host site for the NSAA boys and girls state basketball, as well as the NSAA girls volleyball championships. It has hosted the national roller-skating championships 28 times, beginning in 1962 though the final 2014 meet, called Last Lap At Pershing.[http://journalstar.com/special-section/new-directions/roller-skating-championship-will-need-new-home-in-lincoln/article_1563ae1b-759c-5c3c-95fe-aab30a6ea35a.html - Journal Star] ==Concerts and other events== Pershing has held many events in the past, including concerts and [[WWE]]/[[Impact Wrestling|TNA]] house show wrestling events. [[The Doors]] played their first concert since the death of their singer [[Jim Morrison]] at Pershing on November 12, 1971. The [[Grateful Dead]]'s performance, on February 26, 1973, was recorded and makes up half of their live album, entitled ''[[Dick's Picks Volume 28]]''. The exterior and marquee of the arena are also featured in the 1981 film, ''[[This is Elvis]]'', as it hosted one of [[Elvis Presley]]'s final concerts in 1977. [[Phish]] played the arena in 1995. ==Replacement== In 2008-2009, discussions began to build a new, larger arena for Lincoln due to mid-sized arenas no longer able to meet the demands of most tours. According to Pershing General Manager Tom Lorenz "the music and entertainment industry has pulled back on midlevel tours, reducing the number of shows likely to come to Pershing. Normally, Pershing has six to eight concerts annually, but this year will have three or four".[http://www.journalstar.com/news/local/article_d87d4b92-4ffb-54db-b258-3848563ff376.html - Journal Star] A subsidy to cover a budget shortfall of $150,000 was passed by the Lincoln City Council because the situation was so dire, only "10 months into the fiscal year." The larger arena in Lincoln's [[Haymarket District (Lincoln, Nebraska)|Haymarket District]] was ultimately built between 2011 and 2013, opening as [[Pinnacle Bank Arena]] opened in August 2013. The final major event, a concert by [[Goo Goo Dolls]], was held at the Pershing Center August 6, 2014.http://www.omaha.com/go/concert-review-hit-makers-goo-goo-dolls-close-out-years/article_c257cbf3-994c-5f3b-bf21-432630c512de.html The last usage of the building was a [[roller derby]] match August 23, 2014 between the [[No Coast Derby Girls]] and the [[Kansas City Roller Warriors]],http://nocoastderbygirls.com/?p=3891 it was won by the Kansas City Roller Warriors. ===Future=== An [[Request for proposal|RFP]] was sent out by the City of Lincoln in 2014 looking for reuse plans for the Pershing Center, but none of the proposals were acceptable due to cost. Demolition may be in the building's future if an alternate use is not found.[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/apr/20/lincoln-may-demolish-downtown-pershing-center/?page=all - Washington Times] The contents of the Pershing Center were auctioned off in January-February 2015. http://www.omaha.com/news/nebraska/lincoln-s-pershing-center-equipment-to-be-auctioned-off/article_8bc1859c-9493-11e4-b3ed-e71feb14a1a8.html Members of the community have also voiced their desire to save the large, iconic mural on the auditorium's exterior. Estimates place preservation and re-installation of the mural elsewhere at $1.2 million.http://journalstar.com/news/local/what-is-saving-the-pershing-center-mural-worth-to-you/article_0d0af8b6-e5ad-5b02-9b94-02e84d7cceed.html As of 2018, the auditorium's future is unclear. It remains standing, and is used only as a storage facility for the Pinnacle Bank Arena.http://www.1011now.com/content/news/The-Pershing-Centers-future-raises-questions-about-necessity-affordability-379889491.html Many proposals have been floated by private groups and government agencies, but none that the city government (who does not plan to demolish the building) has found acceptable.http://journalstar.com/special-section/new-directions/city-hall-shuttered-pershing-center-on-prime-real-estate-but/article_1c87e71b-af74-501d-9553-e803d069b265.html ==Gallery== [[File:Pershing Center mural & front entrance, Lincoln, Nebraska, USA.jpg|thumb|left|Pershing Center mural & front entrance]] ==External links== *[http://www.pershingcenter.com/ Pershing Center] (offline) ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Music venues of Nebraska}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Nebraska]] [[Category:Sports in Lincoln, Nebraska]] [[Category:Sports venues in Nebraska]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Lincoln, Nebraska]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lincoln, Nebraska]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Nebraska]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:2014 disestablishments in Nebraska]]

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | name = Saint Stephen's Day bandy | native_name = Anndandagsbandy | native_name_lang = Swedish | logo = | logo_caption = | image = Bandy game 2.jpg | caption = 2004 Saint Stephen's Day game between [[Bollnäs GoIF]] and [[Edsbyns IF]]. | status = active | genre = sporting event | date = 26 December | begins = | ends = | frequency = annual | venue = | location = | coordinates = | country = | years_active = | first = 1930's | founder_name = | last = | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | activity = | patron = | organised = | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = | website = | footnotes = }} {{refimprove|date=October 2014}} '''Saint Stephen's Day bandy''' ({{lang-sv|Annandagsbandy}}) is a Swedish tradition in which elite [[bandy]] matches are played on [[Saint Stephen's Day]].<ref name="annandagsbandy">{{cite news |first= Berndt |last= Rosqvist |title= Festligt och fullsatt på stora bandydagen |url=http://www.dn.se/sport/festligt-och-fullsatt-pa-stora-bandydagen |work=Dagens Nyheter |date=22 December 2003 |accessdate=2010-02-04 |language=Swedish |trans-title=Festive and packed with great bandy day}}</ref>
== History == The tradition dates to the 1930s, when the two clubs [[IF Göta]] and [[Slottsbrons IF]] took to playing a Saint Stephen's Day [[Exhibition game|friendly match]]. Despite initial objections by the [[Church of Sweden]] to scheduling the game on the Saint Stephen's Day, the event grew in popularity thereafter.
Historically, only a few instances of the Saint Stephen's Day match marked the season opener for [[Elitserien (bandy)|Elitserien]], Sweden’s top division. Prior to 1957, Saint Stephen's Day was the date of the final friendly match, after which the season usually started on New Year's Day. In 1957, the top division in Sweden resumed in December, and the Saint Stephen's Day marked the first day of seasons between 1957 and 1961, (the 1962 season began on December 31). From 1963–64 onwards the season began earlier in December, and since the 1966–67 season games have started in November.
There have been efforts, most notably in 1994, to revive [[New Year's Day|New Year's]] bandy and was itself a major event. However, the New Year's game has not been played in the top-tier of the league since the 1981–82 season.
Still by 1999, Saint Stephen's Day bandy was the only major sports event over Christmas in Sweden. Starting in the year 2000, it its popularity led other sports to follow, such as [[handball]] and [[ice hockey]]. Nowadays, people sometimes instead talk of "Saint Stephen's Day sports" ({{lang-sv|Annandagsidrott}}).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{portalbar|Christmas|sports|Sweden}} {{commonscat-inline|Annandagsbandy}}

revision.comment: /* Psychological */
revision.text:
{{redirect|Silver Medalist|the 2009 Chinese film|Silver Medalist (film)}} {{confused|Silver Award (disambiguation){{!}}Silver Award|Silver Star (disambiguation){{!}}Silver Star|silver{{!}}silver metal|Silver Medallion (disambiguation){{!}}Silver Medallion}} {{Unreferenced|date=February 2007}} [[Image:1896 Olympic medal.jpg|frame|right|The [[1896 Olympics|1896 Olympic]] Silver Medal]]
A '''silver medal''' in sports and other similar areas involving competition is a [[medal]] made of, or [[silver plating|plated with]], [[silver]] awarded to the second-place finisher, or [[runner-up]], of contests or competitions such as the [[Olympic Games]], [[Commonwealth Games]], etc. The outright winner receives a [[gold medal]] and the third place a [[bronze medal]]. More generally, silver is traditionally a metal sometimes used for all types of high-quality medals, including artistic ones.
Some governments award military and civilian decorations called Silver Medals. Silver medals can also be awarded by private organizations for achievements in their fields.
== Sports == === Olympic Games === {{main|Olympic medal}} In [[1896 Summer Olympics|1896]], winners' medals were in fact [[silver]]. The custom of [[gold]]-silver-[[bronze]] for the first three places dates from the [[1904 Summer Olympics|1904 games]] and has been copied for many other sporting events. [[Mint (coin)|Minting]] the medals is the responsibility of the host city. From [[1928 Summer Olympics|1928]]–[[1968 Summer Olympics|1968]] the design was always the same: the obverse showed a generic design by [[Florence|Florentine]] artist [[Giuseppe Cassioli]] with text giving the host city; the reverse showed another generic design of an Olympic champion. From [[1972 Summer Olympics|1972]]–[[2000 Summer Olympics|2000]], Cassioli's design (or a slight reworking) remained on the obverse with a custom design by the host city on the reverse. Noting that Cassioli's design showed a [[Roman amphitheatre]] for what was originally a Greek games, a new obverse design was commissioned for the [[2004 Summer Olympics|Athens 2004]] Games. [[Winter Olympics]] medals have been of more varied design.
=== The Open Championship === In [[The Open Championship]] golf tournament, the Silver Medal is an award presented to the lowest scoring [[amateurism|amateur]] player at the tournament.
=== Psychological === Silver medalists were known to suffer "self-recrimination and gold medal envy", particularly those who had lost championship games or missed out of the title by a close score, whereas bronze medalists were usually happy just to make the podium.<ref>[http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/fivering_circus/2014/02 silver_medal_face_the_saddest_looking_second_place_finishers_in_olympic.html]</ref> In many sports with an elimination tournament, including those with a [[third place playoff]] (such as Olympic ice hockey, Olympic soccer, [[FIFA World Cup]]), silver is the only medal given to a team that loses, whereas gold and bronze are earned by teams winning their final matches.<ref>[https://www.sbnation.com/lookit/2018/2/22/17039802 jocelyne-larocque-removed-silver-medal-hockey-usa]</ref>
Notable athletes such as [[Lothar Matthäus]] ([[1999 UEFA Champions League Final]]) and [[Jocelyne Larocque]] (2018 Olympics) removed their runners-up/silver medals right after receiving them; Larocque was later ordered by the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]] official to put her silver medal back on.<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/rules-trump-emotion-as-canadian-womens-hockey-player-ordered-to-wear-silver-medal/article38062105/]</ref><ref>[http://time.com/5170424 canadian-takes-off-medal-olympics/]</ref><ref>[https://www.sbnation.com/lookit/2018/2/22/17039802 jocelyne-larocque-removed-silver-medal-hockey-usa]</ref>
There were some notable exceptions; for instance [[Elizabeth Manley]] (1988) and [[Paul Wylie]] (1992) were pleased to win silver medals in their respective Olympic figure skating disciplines after not expected to be podium contenders entering the competition.
== Military and government ==
Some countries present military and civilian decorations known as Silver Medals. These include:
*[[Austria]]′s [[Silver Medal for Services to the Republic of Austria]] *[[Italy]]′s [[Silver Medal of Military Valor]] *[[South Africa]]′s [[Silver Medal for Merit]] *The [[Civil Air Patrol]]′s [[Silver Medal of Valor]] in the [[United States]].
== Other awards ==
The [[Zoological Society of London]] awards a [[Silver Medal (Zoological Society of London)|Silver Medal]] "to a Fellow of the Society or any other person for contributions to the understanding and appreciation of zoology, including such activities as public education in natural history, and wildlife conservation."
The [[Royal Academy of Engineering]] awards a Silver Medal "for an outstanding and demonstrated personal contribution to UK engineering, which results in successful market exploitation, by an engineer with less than 22 years in full-time employment or equivalent."
==See also== *[[Runner-up]]
== External links == *[https://www.olympic.org/olympic-medals Medal Designs for all Olympic Games]
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Olympic medals]] [[Category:Sports terminology]] [[Category:Award items]] [[Category:Silver|Medal]]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Pankratiast.jpg]] → [[File:Pankratiast in fighting stance.jpg]] [[c:COM:FR#FR2|Criterion 2]] (meaningless or ambiguous name)
revision.text:
[[File:Pankratiast in fighting stance.jpg|thumb|300px|Pankratiast in fighting stance, Ancient Greek red-figure amphora, 440 BC.]] In [[martial arts]], '''stances''' are the distribution, foot orientation and [[body positions]] (particularly the legs and torso) adopted when attacking, defending, advancing or retreating. In many [[Asian martial arts]], the most widely used stance is a [[Partial squat|shallow standing squat]]. This position is generally employed as it is a neutral and agile position from which both attacks and defences may be launched. It provides for the delivery of force when attacking and stability when defending.
Stances vary greatly in their application and form. In general, stances may be described in a number of ways:<ref name="bellaonline.com">[http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art27738.asp A Proper Martial Arts Stance - Martial Arts<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Open or closed== This refers to the lateral distance between the lead and rear foot. In general, open stances are more stable than closed stances. However, open stances leave one vulnerable to groin attacks and expose a larger portion of the body to an opponent.
==Long or short== This refers to the distance from the lead foot to the rear foot. Short stances make the user very agile, but can be unstable. Long stances are very stable, but this is at the expense of agility. Most stances are approximately as wide as the shoulders, though there is significant variation between styles.
==High or low== This refers to the bend in the knees and height relative to a normal standing position. Low stances are very powerful and assist delivery of power through the body to either the arms or the legs. High stances are more mobile and allow one to reposition rapidly.
==Weighted or unweighted== Unweighted stances are those where half of one's bodyweight is on each foot. Forward-weighted or backward-weighted stances place most of body weight on either the rear or the lead foot, respectively. Forward-weighted stances are more aggressive, allowing stronger punches and kicks because one's weight is already forward. Alternatively, backward-weighted stances are more defensive, allowing one to fall back more easily.
Most disciplines have one major stance that they regularly employ (generally from a standard guard position), and many variations of this standard stance which incorporate various combinations of open/closed, long/short, high/low or weighted/unweighted.<ref name="Four basic Karate stances">[http://ndnd.essortment.com/karatestances_rucv.htm Four basic Karate stances<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Typically, martial arts do not teach fighting stances until students have developed other basic skills.<ref name="Four basic Karate stances"/>
==Basic fighting stances== {| class="wikitable" |- |'''English boxing, Thai boxing''' * 2 feet aligned, somewhat spaced apart * standing position |- |}
{| class="wikitable" |- |'''Karate, Wushu, Silat''' * right foot in front, left foot facing left -OR- left foot in front, right foot facing right * crouching position |- |}
== Conceptualising stances and footwork in the martial arts == It is very common in the martial arts to describe stances and the transitions between them in terms of triangles, squares and circles.<ref name="practical-martial-arts.co.uk">[http://www.practical-martial-arts.co.uk/practical_jujitsu/db_stances_triangles.html Stances and Triangles - Practical Martial Arts Copyright 2007 - Keep it Real, Keep it Practical<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This is often done in conjunction with attempts to gain [[positional advantage]]<ref>[http://www.wingchun-kungfu.org/positioning_n.htm Positional Advantage<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927003236/http://www.wingchun-kungfu.org/positioning_n.htm |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> or gain control of the balance of an opponent.<ref name="practical-martial-arts.co.uk"/> In addition, in many styles, specific stances are adopted either for attack or for defence. In addition, many stances are used purely for training, or as progressions to more advanced and practical stances learnt later on.<ref name="bellaonline.com"/>
"Stances are the position from which all attacking and defensive moves begin. They combine balance, defence and readiness. A good basic stance is essential".<ref>[http://www.blackpoolkarate.com/kickboxingskills.htm Karate and Kickboxing Skills, Kickboxing in Blackpool, Karate Stances, Wing Chun Pictures<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Stance types== *[[Forward stance]] *[[Horse stance]] *[[Ginga (capoeira)]] *[[Standing (position)|Natural stance]] (how one stands on his/her feet)
==See also== *[[Karate stances]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{martial arts}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stance (Martial Arts)}} [[Category:Martial art techniques]] [[Category:Partial squatting position]] [[Category:Stances|*]]

English [[intertitles]] | budget = }} '''''The Happy Warrior''''' is a 1925 American [[silent film|silent]] [[drama film]] directed by [[J. Stuart Blackton]] and starring [[Malcolm McGregor]], [[Alice Calhoun]] and [[Mary Alden]].Palmer p.436 The story had previously been turned into a 1917 British [[The Happy Warrior (1917 film)|film of the same title]]. ==Cast== * [[Malcolm McGregor]] as Ralph * [[Alice Calhoun]] as Dora * [[Mary Alden]] as Aunt Maggie * [[Anders Randolf]] as Stingo Hannaford * [[Olive Borden]] as Ima * [[Gardner James]] as Rollo * [[Otto Matieson]] as Egbert * [[Wilfrid North]] as Mr. Letham * [[Eulalie Jensen]] as Mrs. Letham * [[Andrée Tourneur]] as Audrey * Jack Herrick as Foxy Pinsent * [[Philippe De Lacy]] as Ralph (at 8 years) * Robert Gordon as Rollo (at 10 years) * [[Leon Holmes]] as Freckled face boy ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Palmer, Scott. {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
{{Advert|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox Website | name = Thuuz | logo = | screenshot = | caption = Thuuz.com homepage, retrieved 3 May 2011 | url = {{URL|http://www.thuuz.com/}} | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 1,701,745 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/thuuz.com |title= Thuuz.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> | type = Sports information | registration = Required to receive alerts | launch date = 2010 | current status = Active }} '''Thuuz''' (derived from the word "enthusiast") is a sports discovery service that alerts users to sporting events via a proprietary "excitement rating."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/13/weekinreview/13watch.html A Better Way to Watch Sports], ''The New York Times'', 12 March 2011. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref>
==History==
The Thuuz website was launched September 2010 to help sports fans solve the problem of [[information overload]] by identifying the best content "...like your buddy who calls and tells you there’s a great game going on," according to Thuuz CEO Warren Packard.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/article/931173--feschuk-website-helps-fans-get-in-the-good-game Website Helps Fans Get in the (Good) Game], ''The Toronto Star'', 31 January 2011. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref>
On 15 September 2011, Thuuz released mobile applications for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices.<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/p/blogs/gamereport/sports_website_thuuz_rolls_out_its_dfv4Mn2LgBCUa9kN8UiplO Sports Website Thuuz Rolls Out New Mobile App], ''New York Post'', 15 September 2011. Retrieved: 15 September 2011</ref>
Beginning with the 2012 NFL season, Thuuz upgraded its apps to support fantasy sports, alerting fantasy team owners to news, plays and scoring involving their players.<ref>[http://www.maclife.com/article/news/thuuz_sports_update_brings_fantasy_plus_free_2012_nfl_season Thuuz Sports Update Brings Fantasy Plus, Free for 2012 NFL Season], ''Maclife'', 13 September 2012. Retrieved: 27 September 2012</ref>
Thuuz raised $4.2 million in Series A capital funding in September 2012.<ref>[https://techcrunch.com/2012/09/25/sports-discovery-app-thuuz-raises-4-2m-series-a-from-major-tv-partners-to-dominate-your-second-screen/ Sports Discovery App Thuuz Raises $4.2M From Major TV Partners To Dominate Your Second Screen], ''Techcrunch'', 25 September 2012. Retrieved: 27 September 2012</ref> They raised another $6.5 million in funding in June 2017.<ref name="sec-2017">{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1558706/000155870617000002/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml | title=SEC FORM D | accessdate=September 26, 2017}}</ref>
==Overview==
Thuuz attempts to create an objective rating for each game by analyzing live feeds of play-by-play statistics, and measuring six different factors: pace, parity, momentum, social media buzz, novelty, and context. Proprietary algorithms process this data and rate games on a color-coded 0-100 point excitement scale. The score 0-39 is rated as "dull", 40-64 as "OK", 65-84 as "Good" and 85-100 as "Great" with the color becomes darker red as the score increases. Real-time and archived game ratings are displayed. Thuuz also forecasts the ratings for the upcoming games as well.<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/thuuz-aims-to-tip-sports-fans-to-hot-games/article1699729/ Thuuz Aims to Tip Sports Fans to Hot Games], ''The Globe and Mail'', 8 September 2010. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref>
Thuuz sends registered fans live alerts by SMS text or email, permitting a user to tune into a game of interest. Fans may personalize the sports and leagues they are interested in, list favorite teams, and the level of excitement at which they wish to receive an alert.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2011/03/19/134682384/Thuuz-Sends-A-Heads-Up-When-Sports-Get-Exciting.html Thuuz Sends A Heads Up When Sports Get Exciting], ''NPR Weekend Edition Saturday'', 19 March 2011. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref>
Thuuz has teamed with partners such as [[Dish Network]] and [[Google TV]] to integrate Thuuz ratings with televised sports, helping interactive TV viewers to discover, watch, and record exciting games.<ref>[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/dishs-game-finder-app-alerts-154500976.html DISH's Game Finder App Alerts Fans to Games With Best Action as It Happens, Tracks Scores on Screen], ''Yahoo Finance'', 13 September 2012. Retrieved: 27 September 2012</ref><ref>[http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/28/google-tries-again-with-google-tv/ Google Tries Again With Google TV], ''The New York Times'', 28 October 2011. Retrieved: 27 September 2012</ref>
Post-game ratings provide guidance for fans who have recorded multiple events for time-shifted viewing or who wish to watch televised or online replays. Game results are not displayed, so fans can choose the best games to watch without losing the element of suspense, and avoid wasting time on games that turn out to be dull. Thuuz will also suggest the best point in each game to start watching.<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1176370/index.htm You've Gotta See This], ''Sports Illustrated'', 1 November 2010. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref>
Thuuz also employs its algorithms to offer predictions on which upcoming games are anticipated to be most exciting.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703899704576204661653414694 Set Your DVR for the Following Games], ''The Wall Street Journal - The Count'', 17 March 2011. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref>
By aggregating minute-by-minute excitement ratings over the course of a season, Thuuz generates lists of the most exciting games, teams, leagues<ref>[http://espn.go.com/blog/bigten/post/_/id/22734/big-ten-the-nations-most-exciting-league Big Ten the nation's most exciting league?], ''ESPN Big Ten Blog'', 24 January 2011. Retrieved 11 April 2011</ref> performances, and players<ref>[https://www.cnbc.com/id/41739511 Numbers Say Deron Williams Is the NBA’s Most Exciting Player], ''CNBC Sports Biz with Darren Rovell'', 23 February 2011. Retrieved: 11 April 2011</ref> which offer a different perspective than traditional statistics.
Their sole competitor is [[Are You Watching This?!]].<ref name="chatsports">{{cite web | url=http://www.chatsports.com/sports-tech/a/Are-You-Watching-This-Helps-Users-Never-Miss-a-Moment-of-Exciting-Sports-Action-19828 | title= Are You Watching This Helps Users Never Miss a Moment of Exciting Sports Action | publisher=Chat Sports | date=March 12, 2013 | accessdate=March 14, 2017 | author=Sklarin, Jeff}}</ref>
==Coverage== === Professional sports === * [[Baseball]] **[[Major League Baseball]] * [[Basketball]] ** [[National Basketball Association]] * [[American football|Football]] **[[National Football League]] * [[Ice hockey]] **[[National Hockey League]] * [[Cricket]] ** [[Indian Premier League]] * [[Association football]] ** [[Premier League]] ** [[La Liga]] ** [[Fußball-Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] ** [[Serie A]] ** [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]] ** [[Ligue 1]] ** [[Eredivisie]] ** [[Liga MX]] ** [[Major League Soccer]] ** [[Copa del Rey]] ** [[EFL Championship]] ** [[Copa Libertadores]] ** [[Süper Lig]] ** [[Primeira Liga]] ** [[First Professional Football League|First League]] ** [[Scottish Premiership]] ** Belgian First Division A ** [[U.S. Open Cup|US Open Cup]] * [[Tennis]] ** [[ATP Tour]] (Men's) ** [[WTA Tour]] (Women's) * [[Golf]] ** [[PGA Tour]] (Men's)
=== US college sports === * [[NCAA Basketball]] (Men's) * [[NCAA Football]]
===International competitions === * [[Cricket]] ** [[ICC World Cup]] ** [[Indian Premier League]] * [[Rugby union|Rugby]] ** [[Rugby World Cup]] ** [[Heineken Cup]] * [[Soccer]] ** [[UEFA Champions League]] ** [[UEFA European Football Championship]] ** [[FIFA World Cup]] (Men's and Women's) ** [[CONCACAF Champions League]] ** [[CONCACAF Gold Cup]] ** English Football League Cup

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | | stadium_name = University Stadium | nickname = | former_names = Pan American Stadium | image = | location = [[University of Manitoba]] | broke_ground = | opened = 1967 | owner = University of Manitoba | operator = | surface = Natural grass
400m track | construction_cost = $1.1 million CAD{{cite web|url=http://westenddumplings.blogspot.ca/2011/10/university-stadiums-last-hurrah.html|title=University Stadium's last hurrah}} | architect = | tenants = [[Manitoba Bisons]] ([[U Sports]]) | seating_capacity = 5,000 }} '''University Stadium''' is a multipurpose stadium located on the campus grounds of the [[University of Manitoba]] in [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada. It features a 400m 8-lane track, as well as separate areas for [[long jump]]/[[triple jump]], [[high jump]], [[pole vault]], [[Discus throw|discus]], [[Hammer throw|hammer]], [[shot put]], and [[Javelin throw|javelin]]. Inside the track is a large natural grass field used for [[Canadian football|football]] and [[soccer]]. The stadium was home to the [[Manitoba Bisons]] football team until the team relocated next door to [[Investors Group Field]] in 2013. The stadium was originally constructed as the track and field venue for the [[1967 Pan American Games]]. After the games, the stadium was turned over to the University of Manitoba and became home to the university's football team and track and field program. It was upgraded in 1973 and later again prior to the [[1999 Pan American Games]], when a new track and other facilities were installed. The stadium has a permanent seating capacity of 5,000, which has been augmented with temporary seating during major events. The facility is wheelchair accessible, has an adjacent parking lot, and is served by public transit. ==External links== * {{official website|http://umanitoba.ca/faculties/kinrec/bsal/facilities/stadium/}} * [https://maps.google.com/?ie=UTF8&ll=49.806772,-97.146177&spn=0.002448,0.004989&t=k&z=18&om=1 Satellite view of University Stadium on Google Maps] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|49.806708|N|97.146161|W|scale:10000|display=title}} [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Canada]] [[Category:Canadian football venues]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues in Winnipeg]] [[Category:University sports venues in Canada]] [[Category:University of Manitoba]] [[Category:Venues of the 1999 Pan American Games]] [[Category:Pan American Games athletics venues]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Manitoba]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1967]]

[[Borussia Dortmund|Dortmund]]-[[VfB Stuttgart|Stuttgart]], 6 March 2004
[[Borussia Dortmund|Dortmund]]-[[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern]], 17 April 2004

[[Borussia Dortmund|Dortmund]]-[[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern]], 18 September 2004
[[Borussia Dortmund|Dortmund]]-[[FC Schalke 04|Schalke]], 5 December 2004}} | dimensions = {{convert|105|by|68|m|abbr=on}} }} '''Westfalenstadion''' ({{IPA-de|vɛstˈfaːlnˌʃtaːdi̯ɔn|-|}})The syllable that carries the primary stress is phonemically disyllabic {{IPA|/-ˈfaːl.ən-/}}. In normal speech, {{IPA|/ən/}} assimilates to non-syllabic (because of the preceding {{IPA|/l/}}) {{IPA-de|n|}} and attaches to the previous syllable, so that it is pronounced monosyllabically {{IPA-de|-ˈfaːln-|}}. The pronunciation {{IPA-de|-ˈfaːln̩-|}}, with a syllabic {{IPA-de|n̩|}} is not possible. is a [[Association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Dortmund]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], Germany, which is the home of [[Borussia Dortmund]]. Officially called '''Signal Iduna Park''' {{IPA-de|zɪɡˌnaːl ʔiˈduːnaː ˌpaʁk||}}{{Cite web | url = http://www.ruhrnachrichten.de/sport/bvb/bvbnews/BVB-spielt-bis-2021-im-Signal-Iduna-Park;art11635,1640456| title = BVB spielt bis 2021 im "Signal-Iduna-Park" | date = 9 May 2012 | publisher = Ruhr Nachrichten | accessdate =9 May 2012 | trans-title = BVB to play until 2021 in "Signal Iduna Park" | language = German}} for sponsorship reasons, the name derives from the former [[Prussia]]n province of [[Westphalia]]. The stadium is one of the most famous football grounds in Europe and is renowned for its atmosphere.{{Cite news| url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/the-top-ten-football-stadiums-r7pj5mggbc3 | work=The Times | location=London | title=The top ten football stadiums | first=Tony | last=Evans | date=9 August 2009}}{{Cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/03/09/the-20-greatest-stadiums-in-european-club-football/signal-iduna-park-dortmund/ | work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | title=The 20 greatest stadiums in European club football| date=7 April 2016}} It has a league capacity of 81,365 (standing and seated) and an international capacity of 65,829 (seated only). It is Germany's largest stadium, the seventh-largest in Europe, and the third-largest home to a top-flight European club after [[Camp Nou]] and the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium]]. It holds the European record for average fan attendance, set in the 2011–2012 season with almost 1.37 million spectators over 17 games at an average of 80,588 per game. Sales of annual [[season ticket]]s amounted to 55,000 in 2015.{{cite news |author= |date=28 July 2015 |title=Bundesliga-Vergleich - So viele Dauerkarten verkauften die 18 Klubs! |url=http://sportbild.bild.de/bundesliga/2015/bundesliga/so-viele-dauerkarten-verkauften-die-18-klubs-41974370.sport.html |language=German |newspaper=Sport Bild |publisher=BILD GmbH & Co. KG |location=Berlin |access-date=1 August 2015 }} The 24,454 capacity ''Südtribüne'' (South Bank) is the largest terrace for standing spectators in European football.[https://www.derwesten.de/staedte/dortmund/Stadt-Dortmund-sieht-Suedtribuene-als-Denkmal-id2234163.html Stadt Dortmund sieht Südtribüne als Denkmal] (in German) DerWesten, 08.12.2009[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/in-germany-every-game-has-the-feel-of-a-cup-final-says-mcclaren-2080305.html 'In Germany, every game has the feel of a cup final,'] The Independent, 16 September 2010 Famous for the intense atmosphere it breeds, the south terrace has been nicknamed the "Yellow Wall". The Borusseum, the museum of Borussia Dortmund, is near the stadium. The stadium hosted matches in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974]] and [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]s. It also hosted the [[2001 UEFA Cup Final]]. Various national [[Exhibition game|friendlies]] and qualification matches for World and European tournaments have been played there as well as matches in European club competitions. ==History== Plans to construct a new stadium were drawn up in the 1960s, as the need arose to expand and refurbish the traditional ground of Borussia Dortmund, the [[Stadion Rote Erde]] ("Red Soil Stadium"). Following the historic triumph in the [[1965–66 European Cup Winners' Cup|1966 Cup Winners' Cup]] (Dortmund was the first German team to win a European club title), it became clear that the Stadion Rote Erde was too small for the increasing number of Borussia Dortmund supporters. The city of Dortmund, however, was not able to finance a new stadium and federal institutions were unwilling to help. In 1971, Dortmund was selected to replace the city of [[Cologne]], which was forced to withdraw its plans to host games in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup]]. The funds originally set aside for the projected stadium in Cologne were thus re-allocated to Dortmund. However, architects and planners had to keep an eye on the costs due to a tight budget. This meant that plans for a 60 million [[Deutsche Mark|DM]] oval stadium featuring the traditional athletic facilities and holding 60,000 spectators had to be discarded. Instead, plans for a much cheaper 54,000 spectator football arena, built of pre-fabricated concrete sections, became a reality. Ultimately, the costs amounted to 32.7 million DM, of which 1.6 million DM were invested in the refurbishment of the Stadion Rote Erde. The city of Dortmund, initially burdened with 6 million DM, only had to pay 800,000 DM, and quickly profited from the stadium's high revenues. On 2 April 1974, Borussia Dortmund officially moved into their new home and has played in the Westfalenstadion ever since. Having been [[promotion and relegation|relegated]] in 1972, Borussia Dortmund was the only member of the [[2. Bundesliga]] (second Division) to host the 1974 World Cup games in a completely new stadium. In 1976, after promotion to the [[Bundesliga]], Borussia Dortmund played its first game in Germany's highest division in their new home stadium. On 16 May 2001, the Westfalenstadion hosted the [[2001 UEFA Cup Final]] between [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Deportivo Alavés|Alavés]]. ==1974 FIFA World Cup== In the [[1974 FIFA World Cup]], the Westfalenstadion hosted three group stage games and one final group game. The maximum capacity of the stadium was 54,000. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !! Team #1 !!Res. !!Team #2 !!Round !!Spectators |- |14 June 1974||'''{{fb|SCO}}'''||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fb|ZAI}}||[[1974 FIFA World Cup#Group 2|Group 2]]||style="text-align:center;"|25,000 |- |19 June 1974||{{fb|NED}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–0||{{fb|SWE}}||[[1974 FIFA World Cup#Group 3|Group 3]]||style="text-align:center;"|53,700 |- |23 June 1974||'''{{fb|NED}}'''||style="text-align:center;"|4–1||{{fb|BUL|1971}}||[[1974 FIFA World Cup#Group 3|Group 3]]||style="text-align:center;"|52,100 |- | 3 July 1974||'''{{fb|NED}}'''||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fb|BRA|1968}}||[[1974 FIFA World Cup#Group A|Group A]]||style="text-align:center;"|52,500 |} ==2006 FIFA World Cup== The stadium was one of the venues for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. Due to sponsorship contracts, however, the arena was called ''FIFA World Cup Stadium Dortmund'' during the World Cup. Six games were played there during the tournament, including Germany's first loss ever at the stadium, a 2–0 defeat to Italy. Also, Trinidad and Tobago played their first ever World Cup match at the stadium, against Sweden. {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !!Time ([[Central European Time|CET]]) !!Team #1 !!Res. !!Team #2 !!Round !!Spectators |- |10 June 2006||18:00||{{fb|TTO}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–0||{{fb|SWE}}||[[2006 FIFA World Cup - Group B|Group B]]||style="text-align:center;"|62,959 |- |14 June 2006||21:00||'''{{fb|GER}}'''||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||{{fb|POL}}||[[2006 FIFA World Cup - Group A|Group A]]||style="text-align:center;"|65,000 |- |19 June 2006||15:00||{{fb|TGO}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–2||'''{{fb|SUI}}'''||[[2006 FIFA World Cup - Group G|Group G]]||style="text-align:center;"|65,000 |- |22 June 2006||21:00||{{fb|JPN}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–4||'''{{fb|BRA}}'''||[[2006 FIFA World Cup - Group F|Group F]]||style="text-align:center;"|65,000 |- |27 June 2006||17:00||'''{{fb|BRA}}'''||style="text-align:center;"|3–0||{{fb|GHA}}||Round of 16||style="text-align:center;"|65,000 |- |4 July 2006||21:00||{{fb|DEU}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–2 ||'''{{fb|ITA}}'''||Semifinals||style="text-align:center;"|65,000 |} ==Layout== Situated directly next to Stadion Rote Erde, the Westfalenstadion is composed of four roofed grandstands, each facing the playing field on the east, south, west and north sides. The eastern and western stands (Ost- und Westtribüne) run the entire length of the field, while the breadth is covered by the north and south stands (Nord- und Südtribüne). Originally, the corners between the four grandstands remained empty and the spectators appreciated the extensive roof, which covered over 80% of the stands. The eastern and western stands housed the stadium's 17,000 seats, while the 37,000 standing places were housed in the northern and southern stands. {{wide image|Signal Iduna Park Panorama.jpg|900px|align-cap=center|The panoramic view of Westfalenstadion}} Located on the southern terrace of the stadium is Dortmund's "Yellow Wall", which is the largest free-standing grandstand in Europe with a capacity of 25,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/gallery/2012/dec/02/borussia-dortmund-yellow-wall-in-pictures|title=Borussia Dortmund's Yellow Wall - in pictures|first=Gary|last=Calton|date=2 December 2012|website=the Guardian}} The "Yellow Wall" gives Westfalenstadion one of the most intimidating home atmospheres in all of Europe, aiding Borussia Dortmund to an unbeaten home campaign in the [[UEFA Champions League]] in [[2012–13 UEFA Champions League|2012–13]].{{Cite web |url=http://espnfc.com/stats?league=uefa.champions# |title=Archived copy |access-date=4 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230071715/http://espnfc.com/stats?league=uefa.champions# |archive-date=30 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Expansions== [[File:Leeres Westfalenstadion.jpg|thumb|left|Westfalenstadion seen from inside.]] The first expansion plans are dated back to 1961, although the funding required was not available until 4 October 1971 when the city council decided to rebuild the stadium between 1971 and 1974 for the [[FIFA World Cup]]. As part of the extensions an additional roof was added around the stadium that weighed 3000 tons. The original capacity of 54,000 was reduced in 1992 due to [[UEFA]] regulations. As the standing rows on the entire northern, the lower eastern and the lower western grandstands were converted into seats, the capacity shrank to 42,800. With 26,000 seats (of which 23,000 were covered), the seating in the Westfalenstadion now outnumbered the standing rows. [[File:Suedtribuene.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The south stand, ''Die Südtribüne'', is the largest free-standing grandstand in Europe. Fans call it "Die gelbe Wand", which means "The Yellow Wall"]] After Borussia Dortmund won the Bundesliga in 1995, the Westfalenstadion was expanded yet again. In the first private venture stadium expansion in German history, the two main grandstands, the eastern and the western blocks, received a second tier. Covered by a new roof-construction, each section housed an additional 6,000 seats. Thus, the stadium's capacity was restored to the original 54,000, of which the majority (38,500) were now covered seats. Following Dortmund's [[1996–97 UEFA Champions League|1997]] UEFA Champions League victory, success and an ever-growing number of enthusiastic fans made it necessary to enlarge the Westfalenstadion yet again. The southern and northern grandstands were enlarged this time, boosting the total capacity to 68,800 spectators. The southern standing ranks (''"Die Südtribüne"'', where the home team's supporters gather) became the largest free-standing grandstand of its kind in the whole of Europe, with a capacity of 25,000. [[File:Westfalenstadion-207-.JPG|thumb|left|The yellow pylons that give the stadium its characteristic exterior.]] Now it is considered one of the biggest and most comfortable stadiums in Europe. The last renovation was made for the 2006 FIFA World Cup. The stadium has a glass front, under-soil heating (allowing matches in winter) and the biggest terraced stand. It is Germany’s largest stadium capacity of 81,360. The expansion was realised by the German architectural firm of [[Architekten Schröder Schulte-Ladbeck]]. There are four video screens inside the stadium. The fifth screen on the outside of the north stands is smaller, measuring 28 square meters.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} Since 1 December 2005, Westfalenstadion carries the name of Signal Iduna Park, under an agreement which lasts until 2021. When Germany won the World Cup bid in 2000, it became clear that Westfalenstadion would play a leading role in hosting the tournament. [[File:Borusseum.jpg|thumb|right|The ''Borusseum'', a museum about [[Borussia Dortmund]], opened in 2008.]]However, as the Westfalenstadion failed to fulfill [[FIFA]] requirements for hosting semi-finals, it had to be enlarged a third time. Four new stands were built to fill the corners between the existing grandstands, raising the [[seating capacity]] for international games from 52,000 to 67,000. Additionally, the new corner elements provide seating and catering to VIP guests, increasing the total number of VIP seats to 5,000. In order to provide the new sections with an unblocked view of the field, the existing interior roof supports were removed and replaced by exterior pylons, which were painted yellow to suit the Borussia Dortmund colors. During the course of those renovations, construction workers found an undetonated 1,000–pound (450 kg) bomb dropped by an Allied bomber in [[World War II]] that was only about one metre below the halfway line on the pitch. Bomb disposal experts had to evacuate the stadium and surrounding neighbourhood in Dortmund, which as part of Germany's industrial centre was bombed heavily, before taking an hour to defuse the device.{{Cite web |url = http://rt.com/Top_News/2009-02-06/Berlin_airport_a_graveyard_of_WW2_bombs.html |title = Berlin airport a graveyard of WW2 bombs |author = Ciaran Walsh |date = 6 February 2009 |publisher = RT |accessdate = 19 March 2010 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100410192129/http://rt.com/Top_News/2009-02-06/Berlin_airport_a_graveyard_of_WW2_bombs.html# |archive-date = 10 April 2010 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} The stadium now hosts up to 81,365 fans (standing and seated) for league matches, and 65,829 seated spectators for international games. For these, the characteristic Southern grandstand is re-equipped with seats to conform with FIFA regulations. The Stadium is set to undergo some renovation works in 2018 with the stadium's capacity to rise to 81,365 for Bundesliga Matches and 66,099 for international matches.https://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/borussia-dortmund-to-add-6-seats-to-signal-iduna-park-507331.jsp ==Owners== The property of the Westfalenstadion, originally belonging to the city of Dortmund and later sold to the club Borussia Dortmund, was sold to a real estate trust in 2002 when the club was facing serious financial problems. Following that, Westfalenstadion was in the possession of [[Florian Homm]] for about two years,{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} it was sold back to a real estate trust with Borussia Dortmund intending to repurchase the stadium gradually up to 2017. However the club was not able to pay the regular rates in spring 2005 and the holders of the trust agreed in cutting back the asset's interest rates and allowed the club to pay the rates after financial reorganisation. Because of these measures, bankruptcy of the club was avoided and the future of the facility was secured. In 2006 Borussia Dortmund became the new owner by buying the stadium back with the help of a loan from Morgan Stanley. In order to reduce debt, the naming rights to the stadium was sold to an insurance company, [[Signal Iduna]]. From 2005 until 2021, the stadium will be known as the "Signal Iduna Park". During the 2006 World Cup, however, the stadium was called "FIFA World Cup Stadium Dortmund", since FIFA controls all naming rights in connection with the World Cup. ==Transport== [[File:Dortmund Möllerbrücke HDR.jpg|thumb|Subway Station Möllerbrücke]] Signal Iduna Park can be reached with the [[Dortmund Stadtbahn]] (light rail) lines U42 (''Theodor-Fliedner-Heim'' Station), U45 (''Stadion'' Station), U46 (''[[Westfalenhallen (VRR)|Westfalenhallen]]'' Station and also ''Stadion''). The U45 and U46 are unique in that they serve the special station, ''Stadion'', that is open on game days only. Additionally ''[[Deutsche Bahn]]'' serves the ''[[Dortmund Signal-Iduna-Park station|Dortmund Signal-Iduna-Park]]'' station with both regularly scheduled and special game-day trains. This station can be reached using regional [[Regionalbahn|RB]] trains from [[Dortmund Hauptbahnhof|Dortmund Central Station]], as well as from other cities in the metropolitan area, such as [[Hagen]], [[Iserlohn]], and [[Lüdenscheid]]. However, some supporters usually alight the U42 and S4 at the ''[[Dortmund Möllerbrücke station|Möllerbrücke]]'' station and walk to Signal Iduna Park through the ''Kreuzviertel'' via ''Lindemannstraße'' or ''Arneckestraße''. The stadium can be reached from [[Dortmund Airport]] by taking the shuttle bus to the Holzwickede/Dortmund Airport train station, taking train [[Hellweg Net#RB 59: Hellweg-Bahn|RB59]] towards Dortmund Central Station and getting out at ''Signal Iduna Park''. By car the stadium can be reached via the B 1 ''Ruhrschnellweg'' and B 54. Parking is also available at [[Dortmund University of Technology]], where shuttle busses take fans to the stadium. ===Surroundings=== [[File:Kreuzviertel Althoffblock alte Hoeschzentrale von Florianturm.jpg|thumb|Surrounding Area - Kreuzviertel.]] From the subway station ''[[Dortmund Möllerbrücke station|Möllerbrücke]]'' visitors approach the stadium through the [[Kreuzviertel]]. It is well known for its many bars, clubs, pubs, and cafes, concentrated in the vicinity of Kreuzstraße and Vinkeplatz and create a day and nightlife atmosphere unique from the rest of the city. That's the reason why the subway station and the city quarter is popular by local fans and those visiting of Borussia Dortmund as a last resort for drinking a cheep beer in the numerous Pubs around the Stadium. On match days, many traders sell beer, sausages (Bratwurst) and jerseys on the street On the other side of the Autobahn, the [[Trade fair]] with its [[Westfalenhallen]] and TV Tower called [[Florianturm]] affords a marvellous view on the stadium. ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== *Werner Skrentny (Hrsg.), ''Das grosse Buch der Deutschen Fussball-Stadien'', Göttingen: Verlag Die Werkstatt, 2001 *Gernot Stick, ''Stadien 2111'', Basel: Birkhäuser 2005 ==External links== {{Portal|Football in Germany}} {{Commons category|Signal Iduna Park}} * [http://www.signal-iduna-park.de Signal Iduna Park, official site] {{de icon}} * [http://www.bvb.de/?%99%5B%1B%E4%F4%9D Stadium page at the official Borussia Dortmund website] * [http://www.football-match.de/dortmund/ Atmosphere at Signal Iduna Park] {{S-start}} {{Succession box| title=[[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]]
